div.p: THE Fatal Marriage: OR, THE Innocent Adultery.
A PLAY, Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL, BY Their Majesties Servants.
LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonson, at the Judges Head near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleetstreet, 1694.

div.head: TO Ant. Hammond Esq OF SOMERSHAM-PLACE.
div.p:
I Have so many Obligations upon me, that to bring in a fair Account of my Debts, is all that lies in the present power of my Honesty: In the first place, I thankfully confess my self indebted to the good nature of the Town in general: then, in the deepest sense of my gratitude, I acknowledge the Indulgence, and Patronage of particular Men of Quality, who were almost industrious, and contriving for the Fortune of this Play; to make it Considerable to the World, in its Reputation; and to Me, in the Profit of the Third Day. I think it becomes every Mans Character to be pleased with pleasing others; and I know, that to be pleas'd is full as much as I ought to be, upon the success of any thing, that I can attempt in this kind; my Poetry will never run away with me; but the good fortune of finding so many Honourable Patrons, I must confess, has transported me; and if I am a little vain now, 'tis from their good Opinion of me, and not from what I think of my self. I took the Hint of the
tragical part of this Play, from a Novel of Mrs. Behn's, called The Fair Vow-Breaker; Tou will forgive me for calling it a Hint, when you find I have little more than borrowed the Question, how far such a distress was to be carried, upon the misfortune of a Womans having innocently two Husbands, at the same time. I have given you a little taste of Comedy with it, not from my own Opinion, but the present Humour of the Town: I never contend that, because I think every reasonable Man will, and ought to govern in the pleasures he pays for. I had no occasion for the Comedy, but in the three first Acts, which Mrs. Bracegirdle particularly diverted, by the beauty, and gayety of her Action; and though I was fond of coming to the serious part, I should have been very well pleas'd (if it had been possible to have woven her into that Interest) to have had her Company to the end of my Journey. I could not, if I would, conceal what I owe Mrs. Barry; and I should despair of ever being able to pay her, if I did not imagine that I have been a little accessary to the great Applause, that every body gives her, in saying she out-plays her self; if she does that, I think we may all agree never to expect, or desire any Actor to go beyond that Commendation; I made the Play for her part, and her part has made the Play for me; It was a helpless Infant in the Arms of the Father, but has grown under her Care; I gave it just motion enough to crawl into the World, but by her power, and spirit of playing, she has breath'd a soul into it, that may keep it alive. I hope I have, in some measure, discharged my self to the Publick; but for fear of the worst, Sir, I have brought You for my Security, because I always found You in Nature enclining to be responsible for Your Friends; You have allowed me that Title, and I thank You for it; but I value my self upon Your being as heartily disposed to give it, as I was desirous to receive it. I cannot but remember some Passages, that would become Your Character, and this Dedication of my Friendship to You; but I must be silent; and 'tis the hard part of Your Favours, that You won't allow 'em to be acknowledged. I can never speak enough to my Obligation, and never little enough to Your Modesty; when I would be Grateful, I shall be Troublesom; and I know you too well, to think You will be pleased with what I can publickly say of You. Every Man, who knows You, will think I say very little, and they, who are to know You, will find I have
said nothing. You are rising upon the World, and every Creature is the better for You, that's near You; and as Juvenal says of his Emperor, Sat. 7. Materiamque tibi vestra indulgentia quaerit. I may speak of Your Virtues, and good Qualities, though You wont allow me to be a Witness to the World of the frequent Occasions You have found out to employ 'em. If Generosity with Friendship, Learning with Sound Sense, True Wit, and Humour with good Nature, be Accomplishments to Qualifie a Gentleman for a Patron, I am sure I have lit right on Mr. Hammond. I have reason to think I have made You my Friend; and You shall have reason to believe that You have secured me to be,

div.head: To Mr. Southerne, on his PLAY, call'd, The Fatal Marriage; or, The Innocent Adultery.
div.l: AS when some Potentate, whose Princely Care
Governs with equal Reins, in Peace and War,
Drives gently on; and with an easie sway
Compels the Headstrong Subject to obey;
Admir'd by all, yet Grumbled at by some,
(For who e'er sate Unenvy'd on a Throne?)
At length, as Providence has made him Great,
So to make Perfect, what was not Compleat,
The joyful News of a Young Princes Birth,
Comes to fulfil an Universal Mirth:
Then the glad Realm, with Acclamations loud,
As well from Sages, as the common Croud,
Proclaims its Joy, whilst Ecchoes round repeat
The New-born Off-spring Beauteous, as 'tis Great,
Thus Sir amidst the mighty Shouts of Fame,
Which must attend on your Poetick Flame,
Suffer my feeble suffrage in the List;
The Mite was still a Gift, tho' not the Best.
Should I attempt to say what Praise is due,
'Twere to tell all, what they already knew.
So fine your Passions; so sublime your Thought;
All, ev'ry part, so exquisitely wrote;
So short your Repartees, and yet so plain,
That Criticks lose their old accustom'd Aim.
Whilst others Blaze at distance, but when nigh
Afford not half the Pleasure to the Eye,
You, like a well form'd Lamp, disperse your Rays
With equal Lustre, round, in ev'ry Place.
Great is our Joy, with wonder we look on,
To see so fine a Texture, yet so strong:
Whilst through the Theatres, the Court, and Town
Fame speaks aloud, and makes the Author known.
Southern!â€”the Guide, to lead us in the Right,
Great as our Wishes, as our Hopes Polite.
Southerne!â€”The Subject is too Infinite.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
Spoken by Mrs. Bracegirdle.
div.l: WHen once a Poet settles an ill Name,
Let him Write well, or ill, 'tis all the same:
For Criticks now a days, like Flocks of Sheep,
All follow, when the first has made the leap.
And, do you Justice, most are well enclin'd
To censure Faults you know not how to find:
Some cavil at the Style, and some the Actors;
For right or wrong, we pass for Malefactors.
Some well-bred Persons carp at the Decorum,
As if they bore the Drawing-Room before 'em.
Sometimes your soft respectful Spark discovers,
Our Ladies are too coming to their Lovers;
For they who still pursue, but ne'r enjoy,
In every case expect a Siege of Troy.
There are some others too who offer Battel,
And with their Time, and Place, maul Aristotle.
Ask what they mean, and after some Grimace,
They tell you, Twelve's the Time; and for the Place,
The Chocolate-House, at the Looking-glass.
To please such Judges, some have tir'd their Brains,
And almost had their Labour for their pains:
After a Twelve-month vainly spent in Plotting,
These metled Criticks cry 'tis good for Nothing;
But wiser Authors turn their Plots upon you,
And Plot to purpose when they get your Money.

div.head: THE Fatal Marriage; OR, THE Innocent Adultery.
ACT I. SCENE I. The Street.
div.stage: Fabian comes in before Frederick and Jaqueline.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: SUCH an unlucky Accident! such a Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What is't, Fabian?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A catching distemper; 'twill infect every body that comes near me: The Tokens will appear on the Faces of my Friends, in a day or two; and all the Professions they have made to my Prosperity, will cool into a Complement of Condolance; a civil Salutation of the Hat in haste; and end in the usual Form of, Your Humble Servant: with the hearty hope of never seeing me again.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This is the old quarrel between your Father and you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ev'n so: My liberal, conscientious, loving, welldispos'd Father has forbid me his House; and civilly desir'd me to seek my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O, you must expect to be dis-inherited twice or thrice, to try your Obedience, before you're the better for him. But it happens unluckily at this time: What will become of the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Tis that troubles me: to be turn'd out of doors, when I had honestly undertaken the making my Mother-in-Law's, and Sister's Fortune, as well as my own. I have promoted the design as far as I cou'd: I hope you and Carlos will carry it on. There's a Letter from my Sister, [Gives him a Letter. to desire your assistance: I think she wants nothing but an opportunity of running away with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That I have setled in a Letter to her.
I have contriv'd her escape: but how to send it nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That, Sir, I think, falls under my employment: Let me alone for the Letter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: There's an old Gentleman coming this way will certainly deliver it.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Gad, and so he shall: 'tis very well thought upon: Sir, your most humble Servant. The Letter, the Letter, Sir;
I'le do your business, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have left it unfortunately behind me upon my Table: Jaqueline, make haste, and bring it me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I have it in my head to be reveng'd of this old Fellow: Run away with my Sister, be sure, whatever you do: rely upon the old Man's conscience to give her a Portion: all that I can do for youâ€”is to pray (tho' I think there will be no great need of my Prayers) that he will never give you a Shilling.
Carlos, I suppose, knows how to behave himself between a handsome young Lady, my Mother-in-Law, and a Coxcombly old Fellow, my Father. When we are all in Rebellion, a general Pardon must follow.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p:
Sure I saw just now a glimpse of my Rascally
Son shoot by the corner there: Hark you, Friend, was not one Fabian with you before I came?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your Son Fabian, Sir; he was here but just now.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: My Son! hum! he may be your Son, if you like him; for I disown him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, so I hear indeed: 'tis a thousand pities, a pretty Gentleman, as he isâ€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: A pretty Gentleman! yes, truly, he's a very pretty Gentleman: When you can find nothing that a Coxcomb is good for, but to spend money, you cry, he's a pretty Gentleman. What, I suppose you were with him last night, a Serenading (as you pretty Gentlemen call it) but in my language, 'tis catterwawling; good for nothing but to disturb a civil neighbourhood; waken our Wives into wicked wishes; and put 'em in mind of younger Fellows than their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You mistake me, Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I don't know whether I mistake you: but I'm sure, among other his enormities of last night, had not a less Rascal of the Company interpos'd, that Fabian you speak of, wou'd have carry'd me bodily away with him, in the Case of a Base Viol.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay then he is to blame indeed.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: To blame, do you call it!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope I shall make you a better Son, Sir, if you please to accept of me: I have made my applications to you a great while.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; I have plague enough with those Children I have already; I want no more, I thank you. What, I warrant you, you'll say I have a handsom Daughter; why, very well: and every body will say I have a handsom Wife.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, indeed Sir, every body must say your Wife is a very fine Lady.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p:
O, must they so? Why how do I know then, that you han't as great a mind to my Wife, as you have to my Daughter? you look as if you wou'd rather help to bring some more Children into my Family, than take any out of it: But I shall watch you for spoiling my Wife's shape, I promise you. 'Tis very hard upon marry'd Men, that's the truth on't: 'tis
a sin, and a shame, there shou'd be so many ways of making a Cuckold; when there are so few, or none to prevent it. Now are you going to put in a long answer to every particular, but I shall save you the trouble.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, I shan't think it a troubleâ€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: To make me a Cuckold? no, no, I believe you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You won't understand me.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I do understand you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I leave the business entirely to your prudence, to manage according to your discretion.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Is the Devil in the Fellow? because I understand that he has a design upon my Wife, he says, he leaves me to manage it according to my discretion: Why perhaps you expect I shou'd pimp for you: Are not you a very impudent Fellow? or is this your way of proceeding with the Husbands? From this time forward you shall not so much as see my Wife through a double-barr'd window; and to put you out of all other hopes, I will marry my Daughter very shortly to a Friend of my own that will deserve her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you resolve without hearing me?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Resolve! why I do resolve to have nothing to say to you; to you, nor your Rogue there, that follows you. Odd! that Fellow looks very suspiciously.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, say your pleasure of my Master, or to my Master; but don't disparage my Countenance: what have you to say to my Face?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, I don't like it.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Nay, nay, if that be allâ€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: But that is not all: I say moreover that you must be a very impudent Fellow, that can keep such a Face in countenance.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd have you to know, what it seems you are ignorant of, That whatever you take me to be, Sir, I am a Gentleman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p:
Nay, keep your distance, Friend, however. A Gentleman, say you! like enough: take a Pick-pocket into custody, and upon the first question of his Roguery, he shall
answer, I'm a Gentleman. You never hear of a Fellow to be hang'd, tho' for stealing a clean Shirt, but he's a Gentleman; and such a Gentleman I cou'd allow you to be, if you were going to the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: What the Devil shall I do with my Letter? Sir, Sir, under your favour one word; I beg your pardon, Sir; if my Master has said any thing to disoblige youâ€”Lord, Sir, you Lovers have bad memoriesâ€”
My Master has forgot his main business with you, Sir.
You have forgot the Mony you came about, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Mony, Friend! if you come about Mony, I can hear you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What Mony do'st talk of? I want no Mony.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, pardon me; I am your Steward, and know your wants; you do wantâ€”and I wantâ€”
Pox on him, he won't apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There's something to be done with that Letter: I don't understand him, but I'le give into't if I canâ€”
I was loath to discover it, but the best Estates may want Mony sometimes: You shall have what Securityâ€”
sp.stage: [Jaqueline pins a Letter to Fernando's Coat behind.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I am for a Mortgage, or nothingâ€”
What a pox do you mean, gathering about me so?
Have you a design upon my Person?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Sir; well you minded what I said?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Minded what you said! I thank you, I had more occasion to mind what you did: for ought I know I may be robb'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Of your Daughter, in good time.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: My Pockets may be pickt.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Of a short Pipe, and Iron Tobacco-Box.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, this trick won't take.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes, but it will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p:
What then, you design'd to abuse me, to make me
your Property, your Go-between? ha? what shall I do for you? have you no Commendation-token of your affection, or so, to my Wife, nor Daughter? what, you have a Letter; I know. I shall certainly deliver it.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That will be kind, indeed, when my Master sends one along with you.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: At any time, at any time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'm glad I know the way.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: O, you can't miss it by me:
You can't find such another for your purpose.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: By my troth, I think not, Sir; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Do you laugh at your good Fortune already?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Sir, but I must laugh.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Do, do, try with the silly Gentleman, your Master, whether you can laugh me out of my Daughter, or no.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I think I have bid fair for't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Twas pretty well towards it, to make him carry the Letter himself.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: There's no danger of its miscarrying; the whole Family is in a Conspiracy against him; and whoever gets it, will deliver it to Victoria.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know Fabian will do any thing that's mischievous to assist me: Go home, and desire him to stay for me: Behave your self handsomely in this business, and you shall be a Gentleman in earnest. Who's here? Villeroy and Carlos: here, here Jaqueline.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This constancy of yours will establish an immortal Reputation among the Women.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: If it wou'd establish me with Isabellaâ€”

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Follow her, follow her: Troy Town was won at last.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I have follow'd her these seven years, and now but live in hopes.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But live in hopes! why, hope is the ready Road, the Lovers baiting-place, and for ought you know, but one Stage short of the possession of your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: But my hopes, I fear, are more of my own making, than hers: and proceed rather from my wishes, than any encouragement she has giv'n me.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: That I can't tell: the Sex is very various: There are no certain measures to be prescrib'd, or follow'd, in making our approaches to the Women. All that we have to do, I think, is to attempt 'em in the weakest part: Press 'em but hard, and they will all fall under the necessity of a Surrender at last. That Favour comes at once; and sometimes when we least expect it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I shall be glad to find it so.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: You will find it so. Every place is to be taken,
That is not to be reliev'd: She must comply.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I'm going to visit her.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What Interest a Brother-in-Law can have with her, depend upon.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I know your Interest, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Be sure of me to help the Marriage forward.
Why so, Frederick, am not I a very honest Fellow, to endeavour to provide a good Husband for my elder Brother's Widow?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A very kind Relation indeed: you'll give your Consent to the Match, where you are to have the Benefit of the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Tho' I have taken care to root her out of our Family, I wou'd transplant her into Villeroy's.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That has a face of good Nature; but it squints with both Eyes upon your own Interest.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: That trick I learnt in the Schools, in your company, when I was a younger Brother, and design'd for the Church.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Church is a very good School: there are wise Men and Fools of every Foundation: but there are Lessons for every Learner; Doctrines for all Disciples, and calculated to all capacities, to thrive or starve by, as they are able to digest 'em. The Church will teach us to rise in this World, as well as in the next, if we have but Grace to follow her Example.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I think, I have taken care to improve the Principles I receiv'd from her. What did they turn me into a Trade for, but to thrive by the Mystery? and Cheating is the Mystery in all the Professions I know of.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have a great deal of News for you, about Fernando and his Family; the Wife and Daughter are in distress, we must have mercy on 'em.
When you have secur'd the main matter of Villeroy, and Isabella; Julia desires to fall under your consideration.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'm something busie at present;
But I'le take care of her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Here's your Father behind us.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I hope the Old Eves-dropper has not over-heard me.
sp.stage: Enter Fernando, with the Note pinn'd to his Coat.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Who's that dares talk of Love in my House?
It shall be Treason to mention it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your own jealous suspicion; here's nothing
Of Love in this House to be talkt of.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: My own jealous suspicion! it may be so; however, I shall take an occasion to search my House, from the Garret to the Cellar; and if I do find any Love in it, or any thing towards, to encourage itâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: In the Cellar, Sir! what shou'd you find there?
Cold Meat, and small Beer, are no great Provocatives:
Won't you allow us to Eat and Drink, Father?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: To Eat and Drink, Father! thou art always cramming, by thy good will: That Jade's Gut wou'd ruine a little Fortune; wou'd any, but I, were oblig'd to provide for it. Let me see, I don't know but, in my absence, you may have let in some Rascal or another, and hid himâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why don't you look under the Table?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: There's something going forward against me, I know, Gentlewomen, by your always being together: Come, come, what's the contrivance? let me know your design, I'le tell you whether 'twill prosper, or no.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: In short, Husband, I must tell you, your Jealousie has quite tir'd me, and I can live no longer under your Tyrannical Government.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Very well; mine is a Tyrannical Government:
And why, I pray? because it refuses you the priveledge of making me a Cuckold:
A pretty Priviledge truly! and you will plead it as often as you can, no doubt on't:
But I shall watch you.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Hey day! what merry Company has my Father been in?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, do you find me in so merry an Humor, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: In a Humour to entertain us, I see, Sir.
Some body has play'd the Rogue with him.
I'le try to Read itâ€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: The Spirit of Rebellion has been among you in my absence, to perswade you to resist my Lawful Authority: but whether that Spirit appear'd in the simple shape of a Letter only, or in the more lewd Limbs of a Lover, you know bestâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Look you, Wife, if there is a necessity for doing it, do it the cheapest way:
Your Expresses, your Letter-carriers, will cost Mony: Ah! wou'd I cou'd light upon one of those Letter-carriers, I wou'd so pay 'em.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: 'Tis directed to meâ€”
I had almost spoil'd all.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: What is that Wench doing behind me there?
No good I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, but some Fool or other has been chalking you upon the back.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: O! 'twas that Rogue Frederick's Man: I felt him indeed fumbling about me when his Master whisper'd me: but I shall take an occasion to score him over the Coxcomb, when I see him agen.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Did he send it, Father?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Send what, Daughter! wou'd you have had him sent any thing? I cou'd do no more, than offer my Service. He did not like the conveyance, I suppose; and so you are disappointed.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Not I indeed, Father, I'm not disappointed;
I have as much as I expected, or desir'd.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: As much as you expected, or desir'd!

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: What have I to do with him?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Ah! Gypsie! you don't know what you have to do with him?
Nor you don't desire to be instructed?
But if you are ignorant, here's a Woman of Experience:
Your Mother can inform you;
She has something to do with him, if you han't.
Get you gone to your several Chambers, go.
I'le bring you News from your Fellows:
Rely upon me for your Intelligence:
I'le do your business, I warrant you.

div.head: Scene 3. The Street.
div.stage: Villeroy, with Isabella and her little Son.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why do you follow me? you know, I am a Bankrupt every way; too far engag'd ever to make return; I own you've been more than a Brother to me, been my Friend;
And at a time, when Friends are found no more;
A Friend to my Misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: I must be always your Friend.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have known, and found you truly my Friend; and wou'd I cou'd be yours: But the Unfortunate cannot be Friends: Fate watches the first motion of the Soul, to disappoint our wishes; if we pray for Blessings, they prove Curses in the end, to ruine all about us. Pray be gone, take warning, and be happy.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Happiness!
There's none for me, without you: Riches, Name,
Health, Fame, Distinction, Place, and Quality,
Are the incumbrances of groaning Life,
To make it but more tedious, without you.
What serve the Goods of Fortune for? to raise
My hopes, that youat last will share 'em with me.
Long Life it self, the Universal Prayer,
And Heaven's Reward of Well-Deservers here,
Wou'd prove a Plague to me; to see you always,
And never see you mine! still to Desire,
And never to enjoy!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I must not hear you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Thus, at this awful distance, I have serv'd a Seven Years bondageâ€”do I call it bondage,
When I can never wish to be Redeem'd?
No, let me rather linger out a Life
Of expectation, that you may be mine;
Than be restor'd to the indifference
Of seeing you, without this pleasing pain.
I've lost my self, and never wou'd be found,
But in these Arms.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O, I have heard all this!
â€”But must no moreâ€”the Charmer is no more.
My buried Husband rises in the Face
Of my dear Boy, and chides me for my stay:
Can'st thou forgive me, Child?

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Why, have you done a fault? you cry, as if you had:
Indeed now, I have done nothing to offend you:
But if you kiss me, and look so very sad
Upon me, I shall cry too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My little Angel, no, you must not cry;
Sorrow will overtake thy steps too soon;
I shou'd not hasten it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What can I say!
The Arguments that make against my Hopes,
Prevail upon my Heart, and fix me more;
Those pious Tears you hourly throw away
Upon the Grave, have all their quick'ning Charms,
And more engage my Love, to make you mine.
When yet a Virgin, free, and indispos'd,
I Lov'd, but saw you only with my Eyes;
I cou'd not reach the Beauties of your Soul:
I have since liv'd in Contemplation,
And long experience of your growing Goodness:
What then was Passion, is my Judgment now,
Thro' all the several changes of your Life,
Confirm'd, and setled in adoring you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Nay, then I must be gone: if you're my Friend;
If you regard my little Interest,
No more of this; you see, I grant you all
That Friendship will allow: be still my Friend;
That's all I can receive, or have to give.
I'm going to my Father: he needs not an excuse
To use me ill; pray leave me to the trial.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I'm only born to be what you wou'd have me:
The Creature of your Pow'r, and must obey,
In every thing obey you. I am going:
But all good Fortune go along with you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I shall need all your wishesâ€”
Lockt! and fast!
Where is the Charity that us'd to stand,
In our Forefathers Hospitable days,
At Great Mens Doors, ready for our wants,
Like the good Angel of the Family,
With open Arms taking the Needy in,
To feed, and cloath, to comfort, and relieve 'em?
Now ev'n their Gates are shut against the Poor.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, what's to do now, I trow? you knock as loud, as if you were invited; and that's more than I hear of: but I can tell you, you may look twice about you for a Welcome in a great Man's Family, before you find it unless you bring it along with you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I hope, I bring my Welcome along with me.
Is your Lord at home?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My Lord at home!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Count Baldwin lives here still?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Count Baldwin does live here:
And I am his Porter: but what's that to the purpose, good Woman, of my Lord's being at home?

If you had enquir'd for Mrs. Comfit, the House-keeper, or had the good Fortune to be acquainted with the Butler; you might have what you came for; and I cou'd make you an answer: but for my Lord's being at home to every idle Body that enquires for himâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why, don't you know me, Friend?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not I, not I, Mistress; I may have seen you before, or so: But Men of Employment must forget their Acquaintance; especially such as we are never to be the better for.
sp.stage: [Going to shut the door, Nurse enters, having over-heard him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Handsomer words wou'd become you, and mend your Manners,

sp.speaker: Sampson:
sp.p: Do you know who you prate to?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'm glad you know me, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Marry, Heaven forbid, Madam, that I shou'd ever forget you, or my little Jewelâ€”

Now my Blessing go along with you, wherever you go, or whatever you are about. Fye, Sampson, how cou'dst thou be such a Saracen? A Turk wou'd have been a better Christian, than to have done so barbarously by so good a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why look you, Nurse, I know you of old: by your good will you wou'd have a finger in every body's Pie, but mark the end on't; if I am call'd to acount about it, I know what I have to say.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Marry come up here; say your pleasure, and spare not. Refuse his eldest Son's Widow, and poor Child, the comfort of seeing him! she does not trouble him so often.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not that I am against it, Nurse; but we are but Servants, you know: we must have no likings, but our Lord's; and must do as we are ordered.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nay, that's true, Sampson.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Besides, what I did, was all for the best:

I have no ill will to the young Lady, as a body may say, upon my own account; only that I hear she is poor; and indeed, I naturally hate your decay'd Gentry: They expect as much waiting upon as when they had Mony in their Pockets, and were able to consider us for the trouble.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Why, that is a grievance indeed in great Families; where the Gifts at good times are better than the Wages:
It wou'd do well to be reform'd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But what is the business, Nurse? you have been in the Family, before I came into the World: What's the reason, pray, that this Daughter-in-Law, who has so good a Report in every body's mouth, is so little set by, by my Lord?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell you, Sampson; more nor less; I'le tell the truth, that's my way, you know, without adding, or diminishing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ay, marry, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
My Lord's eldest Son, Biron by Name, the Son of his Bosom, and the Son that he wou'd have lov'd
best, if he had as many as King Pyramus of Troy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How! King Pyramus of Troy! why, how many had he?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Why the Ballet sings he had fifty Sons: But no matter for that. This Biron, as I was saying, was a lovely, sweet Gentleman, and indeed, no body cou'd blame his Father for loving him: He was a Son for the King of Spain, God bless him; I was his Nurse. But now I come to the point, Sampson; This Biron, without asking the advice of his Friends, hand over head, as young Men will have their Vagaries, not having the fear of his Father before his Eyes, as I may say, wilfully marries this Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How, wilfully! he shou'd have had her consent, methinks.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, wilfully marries her; and which was worse, after she had setled all her Fortune upon a Nunnery, which she broke out of to run away with him. They say they had the Churches Forgiveness, but I had rather it had been his Father's.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why in good troth, these Nunneries, I see no good they do. I think the young Lady was in the right, to run away from a Nunnery: And I think our young Master was not in the wrong, but in marrying without a Portion.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: That was the Quarrel, I believe, Sampson:

Upon this, my old Lord wou'd never see him; disinherited him; took his younger Brother Carlos into favour, whom he never car'd for before; and at last forc'd Biron to go to the Siege of Candy, where he was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Alack-a-day, poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: For which my old Lord hates her, as if she had been the cause of his going thither.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Alas, alas, poor Lady, she has suffer'd for't:
She has liv'd a great while a Widow.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A great while indeed for a young Woman, Sampson!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Gad so, here they come, I won't venture to be seen.
sp.stage: Count Baldwin followed by Isabella and her Child.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Whoever of your Friends directed you,
Misguided, and abus'd you, there's your wayâ€”
I can afford to shew you out agen.
What cou'd you expect from me?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O, I have nothing to expect on Earth!
But Misery is very apt to talk:
I thought I might be heard.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: What can you say?
Is there in Eloquence? can there be in words
A recompensing Pow'r, a Remedy,
A Reparation of the Injuries,
The great Calamities, that you have brought
On me, and mine? You have destroy'd those hopes
I fondly rais'd, through my declining Life,
To rest my Age upon; and most undone me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have undone my self too.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Speak agen: Say still you are undone, and I will hear you:
With pleasure hear you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Wou'd my Ruine please you.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Beyond all other Pleasures.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Then you are pleas'dâ€”for I am most undone.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: I pray'd but for Revenge, and Heav'n has heard,
And sent it to my wishes: These Grey Hairs
Wou'd have gone down in sorrow to the Grave
Which you have dug for me, without the thought,
The thought of leaving you more wretched here.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Indeed I am most wretched.
When I lost my Husbandâ€”

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Wou'd he had never been; or never had been yours.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I then believ'd
The measure of my sorrow then was full:
But every moment of my growing days
Makes room for woes, and adds 'em to the Sum.
I lost with Biron all the joys of Life:
But now its last supporting Means are gone:
All the kind helps that Heav'n in pity rais'd,
In charitable pity to our wants,
At last have left us: Now bereft of all,
But this last tryal of a cruel Father,
To save us both from sinking. O my Child!
Kneel with me, knock at Nature in his Heart.
Let the resemblance of a once-lov'd Son,
Speak in this little One, who never wrong'd you,
And plead the Fatherless, and Widow's Cause.
O, if you ever hope to be forgiven,
As you will need to be forgiven too,
Forget our saults, that Heaven may pardon yours.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: How dare you mention Heaven! call to mind
Your perjur'd Vows; your plighted, broken Faith
To Heav'n, and all things holy: Were you not
Devoted, wedded to a Life recluse,
The Sacred Habit on, profest, and sworn
A Votary for ever? Can you think
The Sacrilegious Wretch, that robs the Shrine,
Is Thunder-proof?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: There, there began my woes.
Let Women all take warning of my Fate,
Never resolve, or think they can be safe;
Within the reach, and Tongues of tempting Men.
O! had I never seen my Biron's face,
Had he not tempted me, I had not fall'n,
But still continu'd innocent; and free
Of a bad World, which only he had pow'r
To reconcile, and make me try agen.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Your own Inconstancy, your graceless Thoughts
Debauch'd, and reconcil'd you to the World:
He had no hand to bring you back agen,
But what you gave him. Circe, you prevail'd
Upon his honest mind, transforming him
From Virtue, and himself into what shapes
You had occasion for; and what he did
Was first inspir'd by you. A Cloyster was
Too narrow for the work you had in hand:
Your business was more general; the whole World
To be the Scene: Therefore you spread your Charms
To catch his Soul, to be the Instrument,
The wicked Instrument of your curs'd flight.
Not that you valu'd him: for any one,
Who cou'd have serv'd that turn had been as welcome.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O! I have Sins to Heav'n, but none to him.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Had my wretched Son
Marry'd a Beggar's Bastard; taken her
Out of her Rags, and made her of my Blood:
The mischief might have ceas'd, and ended there.
But bringing you into a Family,
Entails a Curse upon the Name, and House,
That takes you in: The only part of me
That did receive you, perish'd for his Crime.
'Tis a defiance to offended Heaven,
Barely to pity you: Your Sins pursue you:
The heaviest Judgments that can fall upon you,
Are your just Lot, and but prepare your Doom:
Expect 'em, and despairâ€”Sirrah, Rogue,
How durst thou disobey me?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Not for my selfâ€”for I am past the hopes
Of being heardâ€”but for this Innocentâ€”
And then I never will disturb you more.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: I almost pity the unhappy Child:
But being yoursâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Look on him as your Son's;
And let his part in him answer for mine.
O save, defend him, save him from the wrongs
That fall upon the Poor.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: It touches meâ€”and I will save himâ€”
But to keep him safe; never come near him more.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What! take him from me!
No, we must never part: 'tis the last hold
Of comfort I have left, and when he fails
All goes along with him: O! cou'd you be
The Tyrant to divorce Life from my Life?
I live but in my Child.
No, let me pray in vain, and beg my bread
From door to door, to feed his dayly wants,
Rather than always lose him.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Then have your Child, and feed him with your Prayer.
You, Rascal, Slave; what do I keep you for?
How came this Woman in?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why indeed, my Lord, I did as good as tell her before, my thoughts upon the matterâ€”

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Did you so, Sir? now then tell her mine:
Tell her I sent you to her.
There's one more to provide her.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Good my Lord, what I did was in perfect Obedience to the old Nurse there: I told her what it wou'd come to.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: What! this was a Plot upon me. Mumper, you, were you in the Conspiracy? be gone,
Go all together;
I have provided you an Equipage,
Now set up when you please.
She's old enough to do you service: I have none for her.
The wide World lies before you: be gone, take any Road,
But this, to beg or starve in: I shall be glad
To hear of you: but never see me more.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: THE Part I act in your Interest, goes against
The grain of my good Nature and Conscience:
But since 'tis necessary to your Service;
And will be my Sister's advantage in the end
I'm better reconcil'd to't.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: My Interest!
O never think I can intend to raise
An Interest from Isabella's wrongs.
Your Father may have interested ends,
In her undoing: but my heart has none.
Her Happiness must be my Interest,
And that I wou'd restore.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why so I mean.
These hardships that my Father lays upon her,
I'm sorry for; and wish I cou'd prevent:
But he will have his way. Since there was nothing to be hop'd from her prosperity, the change of her Fortune may alter the condition of her thoughts, and make at last for you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: She is above her Fortune.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Try her agen. Women commonly love according to the circumstances they are in.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Common VVomen may.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Since you are not accessary to the Injustice, you may be perswaded to take the advantage of other Peoples Crimes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I must despise all those advantages,
That indirectly can advance my love.
No, tho' I live but in the hopes of her;
And languish for th' enjoyment of those hopes.
I'de rather pine in a consuming want
Of what I wish, than have the Blessing mine,
From any reason, but consenting Love.
O! let me never have it to remember;
I cou'd betray her, coldly to comply:
When a clear, generous choice bestows her on me,
I know to value the unequal'd Gift:
I wou'd not have it, but to value it.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Take your own way: remember,
What I offer'd, came from a Friend.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I understand it so. I'le serve her for her self,
Without the thought of a Reward.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Agree that point between you.
If you marry her any way, you do my business.
sp.stage: Enter Frederick and Jaqueline to him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, all goes well, I hope.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: As I cou'd wish. I can't stay with you: I must be near, if occasion be, to lend a helping hand: When this Marriage is over, I design to come in for a snack of Fernando's Family.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The more the merrier, his VVife says.
I hope to dispose of the Daughter my self.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: You Men of Intrigue are commonly lookt upon to be the idle part of Mankind, that have nothing to do: now I am of a contrary Opinionâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why so, Jaqueline?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Because a right good Whoremaster is never at the end of his business.
sp.stage: Enter Fabian in a Fryar's Habit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How! Fabian turn'd Fryar!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
As you see, Frederick; you will all come to a serious sense of your Sins, one time or other, as I have done. I have had a good Father, and I have been an
ungracious Boy to him; that's the truth on't. Therefore to make him what satisfaction I can, for my past faults, I have taken this Habit, with an intention to pray for himâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why thou art not mad, Fabian?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Not mad of a Monastery, I assure you. I am never the nearer being a Saint, for putting on the Habit of Piety: the Profession and the practice of it are two things in the Schools; and wise Men distinguish 'em into several Interests. In short, I have told our honest Abbot the whole History of my Father's Jealousie, Covetousness, and Hardheartedness to his VVife and Children: He, good Man, making it a point of Conscience to contribute as much as he can to a Work of Charity, has giv'n me leave to put on this Habit, for the carrying on the method of his Cure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But what do you propose by this?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why, I propose that every body shall be the better for it, but my Father. For, upon the credit of this my Reformation, believing, from my Cloathing, that I shall have no more occasion for the Transitory things of this VVorld, his Pocket will plead for me, and the old Fellow take me into favour agen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That's something indeed.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Then, in the first place, if you miscarry to Night in your design upon my Sister, I shall be able to deliver a Letter, and bring it about another time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Secondly, I intend to put the means honestly into my Mother's hands, to make my Father a Cuckold, if she pleases.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: These are very good reasons indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Besides these advantages to the Publick, I have a private reason of my own, to be reveng'd upon the Person of the old Gentleman. I must not discover too much of my contrivance, for fear of lessening the pleasure in bringing it aboutâ€”
I shall have occasion of some witty Rogue, that can be mischievous, when there's no danger: I think that's pretty near your Character, Jaqueline.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O, Sir, you do me too much Honour.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Can't you spare him a little?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not well to Night: to Morrowâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Will do my business. I have one part of my Farce, the Fryars will scruple a little: Jaqueline must act that: The whole Fraternity are concern'd in my Plot, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that, Sir; I love a Plot where the Clergy's concern'd: They will always be sure of the Benefit, without the danger of the beating: I am mainly of their Principles.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I am something in haste at present:
To Morrow you shall know more.

div.head: Scene 2. Isabella's House.
div.stage: Isabella and Nurse, Isabella's little Son at Play upon the Floor.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Sooner, or later, all things pass away,
And are no more: The Beggar and the King,
With equal steps, tread forward to their end:
Tho' they appear of different Natures now;
Not of the same days work of Providence;
They meet at last: the reconciling Grave
Swallows Distinction first, that made us Foes,
Then all alike lie down in peace together.
When will that hour of Peace arrive for me!
In Heav'n I shall find itâ€”not in Heav'n,
If my old Tyrant Father can dispose
Of things aboveâ€”but, there, his Interest
May be as poor as mine, and want a Friend
As much as I do here.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: Good Madam, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Do I deserve to be this out-cast VVretch?
Abandon'd thus, and lost? but 'tis my Lot,
The VVill of Heav'n, and I must not complain:
I wonnot for my self: let me bear all
The violence of your VVrath; but spare my Child:
Let not my Sins be visited on him:
They are; they must; a general Ruine falls
On every thing about me: Thou art lost,
Poor Nurse, by being near me.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: I can work, or beg to do you service.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Cou'd I forget
What I have been, I might the better bear
What I am destin'd to: I'm not the first
That have been wretched: but to think how much
I have been happier!â€”VVild hurrying thoughts
Start every way from my distracted Soul,
To find out hope; and only meet Despair.
What answer have I?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why truly very little to the purpose: Like a Jew as he is, he says, you have had more already, than the Jewels are worth: he wishes you wou'd rather think of redeeming 'em, than expect any more Mony upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: 'Tis very wellâ€”
So: Poverty at home, and Debts abroad!
My present Fortune bad; my hopes yet worse!
What will become of me!â€”
This Ring is all I have left of value now:
'Twas giv'n me by my Husband: his first Gift
Upon our Marriage: I have always kept it,
With my best care, the Treasure next my Life:
And now but part with it, to support Life,
Which only can be dearer. Take it, Nurse,
'Twill stop the cries of hunger for a time;
Provide us Bread; and bring a short Reprieve,
To put off the bad day of Beggery,
That will come on too soon. Take care of it:
sp.p: Manage it, as the last remaining Friend, that would relieve us. [Exit Nurse.] Heaven can only tell where we shall find another.â€”My dear Boy!
sp.l: The Labour of his Birth was lighter to me
Than of my Fondness now; my fears for him
Are more, than in that hour of hovering Death,
They cou'd be for my self.â€”He minds me not.
His little sports have taken up his thoughts:
O may they never feel the pangs of mine.
Thinking will make me Mad: Why must I think?
When no thought brings me comfort.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: O Madam! You are utterly ruin'd, and undone.
Your Creditors of all kinds are come in upon you:
They have muster'd up a Regiment of Rogues,
That are come to plunder your House, and seize
Upon all you have in the World, They are
Below, what will you do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Do! Nothing, no, for I am born to suffer.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O Sister! Can I call you by that name,
And be the Son of this inhumane Man,
Inveterate to your ruine? Do not think
I am a-kin to his Barbarity:
I must abhor my Fathers usage of you.
And from my bleeding honest Heart, must pity,
Pity your lost Condition. Can you think
Of any way, that I may serve you in?
But what enrages most my sense of grief,
My sorrow for your wrongs, is, that my Father,
Fore-knowing well the Storm that was to fall,
Has order'd me, not to appear for you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I thank your pity; my poor Husband fell
For disobeying him: Do not you stay
To venture his displeasure too for me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You must resolve on something.â€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Let my Fate
Determine for me; I shall be prepar'd.
The worst that can befall me, is to dye:
When once it comes to that, it matters not
Which way 'tis brought about:
Whether I Starve, or Hang, or Drown, the end is still the same;
Plagues, Poison, Famine, are but several names
Of the same thing, and all conclude in Death.
â€”But sudden Death! O for a sudden Death,
To cheat my Persecutors of their hopes,
The expected pleasure of beholding me
Long in my pains, lingring in misery.
It wonnot be; that is deny'd me too.
Hark, they are coming; let the Torrent roar:
It can but overwhelm me in its fall;
And Life, and Death are now alike to me.
sp.stage: Scene opens, and shews Carlos and Villeroy with the Officers.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No farther Violenceâ€”
The Debt in all is but 4 thousand Crowns;
Were it ten times the sum, I think you know
My Fortune very well can answer it.
You have my word for this: I'll see you paid

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: That's as much as we can desire:
So we have the Money, no matter whence it comes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: To Morrow you shall have it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thus far all's well.â€”
And now my Sister comes to crown the work.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where are these rav'ning Blood-hounds, that pursue
In a full cry, gaping to swallow me?
I meet your Rage, and come to be devour'd:
Say, which way are you to dispose of me?
To Dungeons, Darkness, Death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Have Patience.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Patience!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: You'l excuse us; we are but in our Office:
Debts must be paid.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My Death will pay you all.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: While there is Law to be had,
People will have their own.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: 'Tis very fit they should; but pray begone.
To morrow certainlyâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What of to morrow?
Am I then the sport,
The Game of Fortune, and her laughing Fools?
The common spectacle, to be expos'd
From day to day, and baited for the mirth
Of the lewd Rabble? must I be reserv'd
For fresh Afflictions?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: For long happiness of Life, I hope.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: There is no hope for me.
The Load grows light, when we resolve to bear:
I'm ready for my Tryal.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Pray be calm, and know your Friends.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My Friends! Have I a Friend?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A faithful Friend; in your extreamest need
Villeroy came in to save you.â€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Save me! How?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By satisfying all your Creditors.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Which way? for what?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Let me be understood,
And then condemn me: You have giv'n me leave
To be your Friend; and in that only name,
I now appear before you. I could wish,
There had been no occasion of a Friend;
Because I know you shy to be oblig'd;
And still more loath to be oblig'd by me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: 'Twas that I would avoidâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I'm most unhappy, that my Services
Can be suspected, to design upon you;
I have no farther ends than to redeem you
From Fortunes wrongs; to shew my self at last,
What I have long profess'd to be, your Friend:
Allow me that; and to convince you more,
That I intend only your interest,
Forgive what I have done, and in amends
(If that can make you any, that can please you)
I'll tear my self for ever from my hopes;
Stiffle this flaming Passion in my Soul,
That has so long broke out to trouble you:
And mention my unlucky love no more.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: This generosity will ruine me.â€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Nay, if the blessing of my looking on you,
Disturbs your peace, I will do all I can
To keep away; and never see you more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You must not go.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Could Isabella speak
Those few short words, I should be rooted here:
And never move but upon her Commands.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Speak to him, Sister, do not throw away
A Fortune that invites you to be happy.
In your Extremity he begs your Love;
And has deserv'd it nobly. Think upon
Your lost condition, helpless, and alone.
Tho' now you have a Friend, the time must come
That you will want one; him you may secure
To be a Friend, a Father, Husband to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: A Husband!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You have discharg'd your duty to the Dead,
And to the Living: 'Tis a willfulness
Not to give way to your necessities,
That force you to this Marriage

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: What must become of this poor Innocence?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He wants a Father to protect his Youth,
And rear him up to Virtue. You must bear
The future blame, and answer to the World,
When you refuse the easie honest means you,
Of taking care of him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Of him, and me, and every one, that must depend upon
Unless you please now to provide for us, we must all perish.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nor would I press youâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Do not think I need your reasons, to confirm my gratitude.
I have a Soul, that's throughly sensible.
Of your great worth; and busie to contrive,
If possible, to make you a return.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O! Easily possible!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It cannot be, your way: my Pleasures are
Buried, and cold in my Dead Husbands Grave.
And I should wrong the truth, my self, and you,
To say that I can ever love again.
I owe this declaration to my self:
But as a ptoof that I owe all to you,
If after what I have said, you can resolve
To think me worth your loveâ€”where am I going?
You cannot think it; 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.l: You should not ask me now, nor should I grant.
I am so much oblig'd, that to consent
Wou'd want a name to recommend the Gift.
'Twould shew me poor, indebted, and compell'd,
Designing, mercenary, and I know.
You wou'd not wish to think I could be bought.

sp.speaker: Vil,
sp.l: Be bought! where is the price that can pretend
To bargain for you? Not in Fortunes power.
The Joys of Heav'n and Love, must be bestow'd:
They are not to be sold, and cannot be deserv'd.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Some other time I'll hear you on this subject.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Nay, then there is no time so fit for me.
Since you consent to hear me, hear me now;
That you may grant: You are above
The little forms, which circumscribe your Sex.
We differ but in time, let that be mine.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You think fit
To get the better of me, and you shall;
Since you will have it soâ€”I will be yours.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I give you all,
My hand; and would I had a heart to give:
But if it ever can return again, 'tis wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O extasie of Joy!
Leave that to me. If all my Services,
If prosperous Days, and kind indulging Nights,
If all that Man can fondly say, or do,
Can beget Love, Love shall be born again.
O Carlos! now my Friend, and Brother too.
And Nurse, I have Eternal thanks for thee.
Send for the Priestâ€”
This Night you must be mine.
Let me command in this, and all my Life
Shall be devoted to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: On your word
Never to press me to put off these Weeds,
Which best become my melancholly thoughts
You shall command me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Witness Heav'n and Earth
Against my Soul, when I do any thing
To give you a disquiet

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I long to wish you Joy.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You'l be a Witness of my Happiness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: For once I'll be my Sisters Father,
And give her to you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Next my Isabella,
Be near my Heart: I am for ever yours.

div.head: SCENE the Street before Fernando's House.
div.stage: Enter Frederick and Jaquelin, with a Dark Lanthorn, and a Ladder of Ropes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well! This is the time; and that's the Window.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: And here is a Ladder, to put her in mind of her fortune.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How's that, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, Lord, Sir, if the Gentlewoman be Mad enough to run away from her Father, upon your account, she'l carry the frolick a little farther, in a Fortnight, and hang her self, upon her own.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why, you Rogue, I'm in love with her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I am but your poor Servant, Sir, and if you command me to be believe you, 'tis another thing.
But I know what your love commonly ends inâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: In a Week, Sir; but that's her business, and not mine; unless the spirit of her Revenge, rises upon the folly of her Pride, and frightens her into the consideration of your humble Servant, Jaqueline,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O! You are witty, Sir! The Window opens.
sp.stage: [Victoria above, a Night-Gown over her Mans Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I heard a noise: I'll listen.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Here am I, expecting the good hour.
Boy or Girl, chuse you whether,
So we once but come together.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Here's your Deliverance in a Halter, Madam,
A Ladder of Ropes for you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I had rather have it in a Halter,
Than stay where I am: Give it me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Be sure you fasten it above.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Any thing to get loose below.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O the discretion of a Girl! She will be a Slave to any thing, that has not a title to make her one. If my Master does commit Matrimony, which he is not much addicted to, 'tis but changing a Father for a Husband: removing from one Prison to another; but that has an appearance of Liberty for the time; tho' it ends in a worse confinement at last.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Well! The Ladder that is to convey me, is ready;
But before I part with this World, 'twould be
But reasonable to have a little Consolation,
To encourage my Journey to the next.
What am I to trust to, when I come there?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: My Master, Madam; what should you trust to?
You can't trust an honester Gentleman, who, to my knowledge, will more infallibly break his word with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What should you trust to, but your self, Child?
Rely upon your beauty: 'twere a disparagement
Of that, to talk of Conditions, when you are certain of making your own terms.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Nay, now is my time indeed; and 'twill be my
Own fault, if I don't: I shall shift, as my Neighbours
Daughters have done before me, if I am left
To the wide World. But, Frederick, as to your particular.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.p: Why my particular is at your Service, and pray come down, and be satisfied; Lord, here's such a-do to perswade a Woman to her Liberty.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I'm answer'd, I'm answer'd, and coming down as fast as I can: any thing to get rid of this Father.
sp.stage: Fernando enters to her Arm'd, and turns her away from the Window.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Say you so, Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Undone, and ruin'd! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I'll tell you what you shall do; get you in, Hussy, go.â€”Now will I personate this hopeful young Jade; and, by that means, discover the whole Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: What's that!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What's what? where?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: There's certainly a noise at the Window above.
I'll turn the blind side of my Lanthorn,
For fear of being discover'd.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.p: You Blockhead, the noise was in the Street.â€”Victoria.â€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Ay, ay.
Where are you, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I am here, my Deat.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Are you sure you are there, Madam? For my heart misgives me plaguily about this Father of yours.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Does it so, Rogue enough?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: You had best make haste: Old Argus will have an Eye upon you, and thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You'l slip your Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I'll lay hold ontâ€”and your Ears, when I come within reach of 'em.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Are you coming?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Now, speak softly. [Fernando goes down the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Look you to the Ladder:
I'll call the Chair to carry her off.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'll lead you to my Master, Madam;
Pray give me your hand

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: There 'tis for youâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: By my troth, and so 'tis; but not quite so soft, as might be expected from a Lady: Sure you, or I, are mistaken, Madam.
Mercy upon me! what do I see!

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, what do you see? You see the Party you expected to see; don't you, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: The Devil, the Devil, the Devil.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: You lye, you lye, like a Rogue,
I am none of the Devil; but I will make a Devil of you before I have done with you: I'll disappoint you of a Halter, and send you a nearer way than you thought of.
Have at you.
sp.stage: [Presenting a Blunderbuss at him, Jaqueline falls, Frederick runs and Disarms Fernando.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Deliver us from a Blunderbuss.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, a thousand thanks to you: I am not perfectly satisfy'd whether he has kill'd me, or no; But if I am Dead, I shall be glad to hear the Old Rogue was hang'd for me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who are you, that wou'd Murder my Servant?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: One that wou'd do as much for his Master.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Oh! he's the Devil of a Fellow; take care of him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fernando! how came you here?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why your Mistress, and my damn'd Daughter, not being quite ready to run away with you, desir'd me to make her excuse, and come down in her room to receive you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: My reception was a little extraordinary: Pox take you.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Gentlemen, I am a little unprovided at present to entertain you; but my Servants are up in the House, I'll get them together as fast as I can; and then you shall be sure of a welcom.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Unlucky Disappointment!

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: No, no, no disappointment in the World: Stay but a little, I'll bring my Daughter my self to you; you shan't be disappointed.
sp.stage: [Victoria in mans Clothes opens the Door, comes forward and meets Fernando.
sp.p: How's this! my Door open! and a Man come out of my House! Who are you? What wou'd you have? Thieves! Thieves! lay hold upon him: I charge you in the Kings Name to secure himâ€”Thieves, Thievesâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: As you are Gentlemen protect me; I am no Thief.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How do we know that, Friend? 'Tis very suspicious.â€”

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Ay, ay, they are your Accomplicesâ€”I shall be with youâ€”Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: If you don't find me worth your protection, when you know me, do what you please with me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That's fair enough, Sir, we had best draw off in time; the House will rise upon us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A Pox on this unlucky adventure. Poor Victoria, she must pay for all.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Fire, fire, you'll be burnt in your Beds; will no Body come to me?â€”Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: How came my Doors open? Where's my Wife? Bid my Daughter come down. I have lostâ€”I don't know what I have lost. They may be Plotters against the Government for ought I know; run every way to apprehend 'em.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: This way, this way.
sp.stage: The Scene changes; Enter Frederick, Victoria, and Jaquiline.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: A little of the Old Rogues broad Gold would have purchas'd your Pardon if you had Robb'd him: I was in hopes of a snack of the Plunder.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: My design lay another way, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But that we must not enquire into.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Why, faith, yes, If you please. I am so much oblig'd to you for my Deliverance, I'll make nothing a Secret to you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if it be a Secretâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Twere not worth telling, Sir, if it were not a Secret.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: It is a Secret, indeed, as every thing ought to be, when there's a Woman in the case.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is there a VVoman in the case then?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: A very pretty Woman; but you are a Man of Honorâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq
sp.p: That he is upon my word, Sir; my Master is as good at a Ladies Secret as you can be, and will betray it to no bodyâ€”before he has discover'd it himself.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: And therefore I will honestly own to you, that my business was with Victoria, Fernando's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With Victoria!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: This Fool will discover himself to his Rival.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Does Victoria know of your business?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Know of my business! Why I make Love to her. I have had an Intrigue with her these three months: I am almost tir'd of her. I lye with her every Night in her Fathers House, and the Devil's in't if she is not acquainted with my business.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: It must be your fault, if she is not, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Now you must know her Father is Jealous of every body for her, but me; there's one Frederick has a design upon her, she has given him some Encouragement of late, for the sake of her Liberty. I thank her, she has thought him fitter for the Fortune of her Husband than I shou'd be; she designs to Marry him, good Man, for her convenience; and I am to continue upon all occasions of Pleasure, as I tell you, Sir, her Ladiships humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You will have a rare time on't with this Fool of a Husband.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I shall manage him, I warrant you; do you know him?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have seen him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I have the Honour to know him a little too.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: And what do you think of him?
Does he promise to be a Cuckold by his Countenance?

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.p: Why, faith, no, I thought not

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: But there's no faith in Faces, you know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It seems so indeed by what this Gentleman has told us; But Sir, do you know your Cuckold? This Frederick?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I know him

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Hold up your Lanthorn Jaqueline
sp.stage: [The Lanthorn held up to Frederick's face.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Bless me! who are you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That very Man, the Frederick you speak of; your Cuckold that is to be.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir, why then you are oblig'd to me for telling your Fortune beforehand; you may avoid it if you please; I have giv'n you warning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But I must reward you for your care of me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty impudent Fellow, and I'm sorry for him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, if I believ'd any thing that you have said of Victoria, I wou'd not think you worth a beating upon her account: I wou'd leave you to your Vanity, and her to the folly of throwing her self away upon such a Rascal; but I know you lye; yet I'll use you better than you deserveâ€”Drawâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Not in the dark; besides you are two to one. I scorn to recant what I said; and to morrow as soon as you pleaseâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shan't part with you so, you shall go home with me to Night, that I may be sure of you in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: With all my heart; you know me well enough, and when you see my faceâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pray let us see itâ€”
sp.stage: [Jaqueline holds the Lanthorn to her face.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: You will believe that I am moreâ€”aâ€”Woman of Honour, than to refuse a Gentleman any reasonable satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I believe my Eyes! Victoria!

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Now I won't part with you, Sir, what say you? Shall I go home with you to Night, that you may be sure of me in the Morning?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I will be sure of thee to Night, Child.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: No, not to Night; nothing in the dark, as I told you before.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am confounded at your escape; your manner of making it; your Fathers coming down upon us; your Mans Clothes; and aâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Never wonder at a Womans Invention: We have Wit enough for our own Affairs, I warrant you. In a design of pleasing our selves, you find, one way or other we bring it about.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You have play'd the Rogue with me, Victoria, but I shall be reveng'd of you.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Why, you won't offer to Marry sure, after the character you have had of me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have had fair warning indeed, but he must have more Grace than I, who can take warning of any thing he has a mind to.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Marriage is a bold venture at the best.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But where we please our selves we venture least.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I. Fernando's House.
div.stage: Fernando meeting Fabian in a Friars Habit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: HOW now, Son, what News with you? Bless you, bless youâ€”tho' I am but in an indifferent humor, of Blessing at present.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Sir, I come out of my Duty to see you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why, that's well: I am lusty, as to that matter still, but your Sister, like a vagrant, a vagabond Jade, is run away from me: Let her alone, see who'll have the worst on't; thy Estate will be the better for it by some Thousands.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Alas! my Estate, Sir! I have done with the things of this World.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, I don't perswade you; I wou'd not go about to alter your Holy resolutionâ€”But a Scurvy Jade! if I had known of her Disobedience a little sooner, I cou'd have the better afforded to have been kinder to theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: You have been kinder than I deserv'd, in forgiving me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: For I am afraid I was not so kind as I shou'd have been to theeâ€”ha?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: O dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Indeed I am; there might be faults on my side; If truth wou'd out, I believe I lov'd my Money a little too well, did I not? ha?

sp.speaker: Fab
sp.p: I did not deserve it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: But I'll make thee amends. We old Fellows seldom think of doing good for our Children, till they are out of the way of receiving it. Well, and how dost thou like a Religious Life? ha?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why, very well, 'tis better than rambling up and down the Town, spending thy time and Money with the Prophane. When I die, I shall leave a swinging Legacy to the Monastery, upon thy account.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Upon your own, Sir, we shall pray for you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No, no, I'll not put you to the trouble.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: And help you out of Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ah! my Purgatory is in this World; and a young Wife my Tormenter. Good Son call her to me.

Let me see, I have lost my Daughter, but then I have saved my Money; all Daughters are lost to their Parents, one time or other; why then the cheapest way of getting rid of 'em, is always the best for the Family. If Frederick has got her, and will play the Honourable Fool to Marry her, for Love, that is, without a Penny of Portion; he is in the way of repenting his Bargain, and not I, I take it; but then I shou'd have Married her to my old Friend Franciscoâ€”why, my old Friend Francisco is luckily rid of a damn'd young Wife, that wou'd as certainly have made him aâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.p: A what, Husband?? as who? you are always bringing your filthy Comparisons into the Family: You put this business so often into my Head, it may â€¢ a â€¢â€¢ upon your own, one day.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, Wife, I did not mean thee; that undutiful Daughter of mine! was reflecting upon; ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ us! I warrant you, ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ time! We shall ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ her ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ up, full of
the Experiment, with a pitiful Petition for Pardon, and Portion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not if she be wise: What Woman that has but the least sense of what it is to be happy, would not prefer want, hunger, any thing, to such an intollerable Slavery?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why then you are of her opinion, it seems?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Have a care of making me so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I shall have a care of other Peoples making you so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Jealousie, and ill Usage may do much.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: A good opportunity may do more.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One with the other, Husband.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Wou'd make you run away from your Husband? ha?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ay, and run to another Man too; any thing, if my Virtue would permit me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Your Virtue! ah! when I stand to the mercy of your Virtue, I'll be contented to fall by that folly: No, no, I have a trick worth two on't: I'll keep you out of the temptation, and then 'tis not much matter whether you have any Virtue, or no.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray, do, lock me up, that your Neighbours may know you dare not trust me at your Kinsmans Wedding.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Sir, you and my Mother are invited: Villeroy is your Relation, and will take it ill, if you don't go.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Wife, we will goâ€”

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Or I shall be disappointed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hanging days are commonly Holy-days; I love to see the execution of a Husband: They have had their jest long enough upon me, I shall be glad to laugh in my turn. Besides, 'tis a publick Wedding, is it not?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why, What's that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Tis kept publickly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why so much the better; there's less danger of you, Wife: These publick Entertainments seldom do any body hurt, but those that make 'em. All the young Fellows I know will be designing upon the New Married Woman; you must not take it ill, Wife; every one in their turn, you have had yours already. When the Husband invites, 'tis a sort of a mannerly gratitude to be civil to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: They say indeed, whoever dances with the Bride, the Husband pays the Fidler.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let 'em all dance with her, if Cuckolds would honestly declare themselves, their number would go near to keep 'em in countenance: I hope to see 'em so much in fashion, that no body may laugh at his Neighbour.

div.head: SCENE II. Isabella's House.
div.stage: Carlos, with Frederick, and Victoria, in Mans Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are the strangest Woman in the World, run away from your Father, and then scruple to Marry the Man you ran to!

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: That will admit of a scruple, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Don't you believe I love you?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: O, yes, Sir, your present inclination may be good, I believe: But that present inclination, how long will it last, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There's a question for a Lover indeed!

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: When that begins to tire, as every thing is the worse for the wearing, they say, how many Husbandly reflections will you have upon the matter! You will find out a thousand pretty things you cou'd have done with my Portion; but not one civil thing with my Person, without it: The Woman, that plays the fool my way, in running from her Friends, must have more than she can carry about her, to be welcome long in a place; and Marriage is only for Life, they say.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I gad, she's in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What can you say to this Frederick.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Nay, he can say more than I can believe, I assure you: But I won't put him to the expence of his Conscience. When I see which way my Brothers Plot works upon my Father, I shall be able to tell you more of my mind. In the mean time I have the priviledge of my disguise, to be at the Entertainment of this Wedding.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But you'll get such a habit of wearing the Breechesâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: When you get me out of 'em, you must keep me out of 'em; that will be your way I believe; Not but if you care for a security, you have a pretty good one upon me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: As how pray?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Why, I have done too much with you, to do any thing with any body else; I shan't be twice run away with, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I dare rely upon youâ€”
Now, Carlos, every thing's to your mind.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have taken a great deal of pains to bring it about. The severity of my Sisters Widowhood, was the only bar to my hopes, in favour of her Son.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This Marriage has removed that.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And ruin'd 'em for ever with my Father.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How will you be able to thank 'em for the service they have done you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The service pays it self; We are all pleas'd, I should have visited 'em with a formal Epithalamicun â€¢ , to bless their endeavours; but I have a Sonnet is pretty well to the purpose. Strike up Boysâ€”'Tis not much matter now, whether my Brother be alive, or no.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: No news of the Bride or Bridegroom yet?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: We are going to summon 'em.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: By this time, I suppose, they may be glad of a handsome excuse to be rid of one another.

div.head: A SONG set by Mr. Purcell, and Sung by Mrs. Hudson.

lg.l: THe danger is over, the Battle is past,
The Nymph had her fears, but she ventur'd at last,
She try'd the encounter, and when it was done,
She smil'd at her folly, and own'd she had won.
By her Eyes we discover the Bride has been pleas'd;
Her blushes become her, her passion is eas'd;
She dissembles her joy, and affects to look down:
If she Sighs, 'tis for sorrow 'tis ended so soon.
Appear all you Virgins, both Aged and Young,
All you, who have carri'd that burden too long,
Who have lost precious time, and you who are loosing,
Betray'd by your fears between doubting, and chusing:
Draw nearer, and learn what will settle your mind:
You'l find your selves happy, when once you are kind.
Do but wisely resolve the sweet venture to run,
You'l feel the loss little, and much to be won.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Who's there? my Carlos! Frederick! O my Friends!
Let me embrace you: Welcome, welcome all.
What shall I say to you, that may express
My thanks for this good Morrow? at a timeâ€”

sp.speaker: Car. and Fred.
sp.l: We came to wish you Joy.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I have it sure;
All that this Life can give me; he must be
More than a Man, who can be happier.
I am so much transported with the thoughts
Of what I am, I know not what I do.
My Isabella! But possessing her,
Who would not lose himself? You'l pardon me
Oh! There was nothing wanting to my Soul,
But the kind Wishes of my loving Friends;
And now I have you to rejoyce with me.
Where are my Servants?
Gentlemen, this Purse will tell you that I thank you.
Where, where are you?
Are my Friends invited? Is every thing in order?
