You cannot be too busie in your care.
Pray put on your best looks, as well as Cloaths.
Gold, that does every thing, shall make you smile:
Carry an Invitation in your Face,
To every one you see; no matter who.
I'll double all your Wages; nothing appear
Within these Walls, but Plenty, Mirth, and Love;
An Universal Face of Joy, and Love.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why this is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O when you all get Wives, and such as mine,
(If such another Woman can be found)
You will Rave too, Doat on the dear content,
And prattle in their praise, out of all bounds:
No matter what the Fools of form shall say,
Let 'em believe us Mad; we'll pity them,
And their dull want of knowing how to Love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If you would talk calmly, and come to particulars,
We might be the better for the Story.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Particulars! How? Which way shall I try
To utter my full bliss? 'Tis in my head,
'Tis in my Heart, and takes up all my Soul:
The labour of my Fancy, and too vast
A Birth of Joy, to be disclos'd so soon.
Imagination must devour it self.
About some twelve Months hence, I may begin
To speak plain sense; and then I'll rell you all.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: This Matrimony would be a Heavenly thing,
If the first Night would last always.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Sir, I must beg your pardon: Pray forgive me
I did not see you sooner.â€”
A pretty Gentleman.â€”

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A Friend of ours.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Sir, I am one, just upon the precipice
Of Marrying; and come here to try whether I like
The condition in my Friends,
Before I venture on't my self.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O Sir! You can't do better:
I shall make Converts of you all in time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He does not know you.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: I'm glad on't; 'twould lay a restraint upon me,
If he did, which I have no mind to at present.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He might take the priviledge of a Relation,
Perhaps to censure your Conduct.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: That is to say, you would if you durst:
But when I marry you, I'll give you leave.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Does Villeroy know of Fabians plot upon his Father?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes; and approves of it, for the good of the Family:
That was the chief reason of inviting him.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Unlucky accident! my Brother the Arch-Bishop of Malines,
Intending for Bruxelles, is taken desperately ill:
My Letter presses me to be with him to Night.
It must be so.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis hard indeed.â€”

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To leave your Bride so soon.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But having the Possession of my love,
I am the better able to support
This absence, in the hopes of my return.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your stay will be but short.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It will seem long.
What say you to some cooling Wines, or Fruit,
Till the Brides Dress'd?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Frederick, I hear you are a Bridegroom too:
Your a bold Man to Marry my Cosin Victoria,
Without her Father's leave:
But we'll take pains to make up all again.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Ay, marry Nurse, here's a Master indeed!
He'll double our Wages for us! If he comes on
As fast with my Lady, as he does with her Servants,
We are all in the way to be well pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: He's in a rare humour; if she be in as good a oneâ€”

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: If she be, marry, she may e'en say,
They have begot it upon one another.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well! why don't you go back again to your old Count?
You thought your Throat cut, I warrant you,
To be turn'd out of a Noblemans Service.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: For the future, I will never serve in a House,
Where the Master, or Mistress of it lies single:
They are out of humour with every body, when
They are not pleas'd themselves. Now this going
To Bed together, makes every thing go well:
There's Mirth, and Money stirring about,
When those matters go as they should do.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Indeed a good Bed-fellow, Sampsonâ€”

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Ah Nurse! A good Bed-fellow is a very good thing, And goes a great wayâ€”But, what, now my Lady is marry'd, I hope we shall have company come to the house: There's something always coming from one Gentleman, or other, upon those occasions, if my Lady loves Company.

sp.speaker: Nurse,
sp.l: Add so, my Master! We must not be seen.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You say 'tis innocent?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Only a sleeping Draught, to make him forget some
Of his ill humours: when it works, he'll be thought
To have tipled too much, that's all: I'll remove him
With as little trouble, as possible.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Is he coming?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: He's below; I'll way-lay him with a Bottle in a Corner,
And give him his Dose before you see him.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: That as you please. Pray tell the company
The bride will wait upon 'em.
My Isabella! O the joy of Heart!
That I have leave at last to call you mine.
When I give up that Title to the Charms
Of any other wish, be nothing mine.
But let me look upon you! View you well;
This is a welcome Gallantry indeed:
I durst not ask, but it was kind to grant,
Just at the time: dispensing with your dress
Upon our Bridal-Day.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Black might be ominous;
I would not bring ill luck along with me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O! if your melancholly thoughts could change
With shifting of your Dressâ€”Time has done cures
Incredible, this way, and may again.
'Tis something that the face of Heavn appears;
Darkn'd, and hid so long in Mourning Veils:
When breaking Clouds divide, they make a way
For the bright Sun to smile upon the Day.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I cou'd have wish'd, if you had thought it fit,
Our Marriage had not been so publick.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Do not you grudge me my excess of Love;
That was a cause it could not be conceal'd:
Besides 'twould injure the Opinion,
I have of my good Fortune, having you;
And lessen it in other Peoples thoughts,
Busie on such occasions to enquire
Had it been private.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have no more to say.
sp.stage: Carlos, Frederick, Victoria, other Men and Women enter.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Our Friends too, who come in to the support
Of our bad Fortune, have an honest right,
In better times, to share the good with us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We come to claim that right, to share your joy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: To wish you joy; and find it in our selves;
For a Friends happiness reflects a warmth,
A kindly comfort into every heart,
That is not envious.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: He must be a Friend,
Who is not envious of a happiness,
So absolute as mine; but if you are,
(As I have reason to believe you are)
Concern'd for my well-being, there's the cause:
Thank her for what I am, and what must be.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Is not this better than lying alone, Madam?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You'l take my advice another time, Sister.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: You Ladies are hard to be persuaded to please
Your selves: but you know when you are well, I hope.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: When you are well pleas'd he means, Sister.
You are a Judge, and within the degrees
Of comparison, having had a Husband before.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Carlos, what have you done? A rising smile stole from her thoughts, just redning on her Cheek, and you have dasht it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: My best friends will forgive me when I own I must prefer her Peace to all the world. Pray let us bury every thing that's past; look forward to the kindly coming hour. I have a prospect of sufficient Joy; wou'd you had all to entertain your hopes, and draw you on to everlasting Love.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Why, so, so; all goes well I see: Wish you Joy,
Cosin. I am an Old Fellow, but I must salute your Bride.
A fine Woman truly! I have had two or three Glasses to her
Health already: I design to be very merry, ha?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Why, so you shall Cosin; fill some Wine.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, that's well said; fill some Wine. But one word with youâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I did not know you at first.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: If my Father does not, I shall have the pleasure of teazing him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your Brother has taken care that he shall know no body.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: If you had consulted me, I could have told youâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: What, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, that there goes a great deal of pains to keep a handsom Wife to ones self; remember I told you so.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Take care of your own, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Why, that's true tooâ€”
Where are you? how! what have you to do with this Gentle-woman, Friend?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I wou'd have something to do with her, if you wou'd let us alone.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to disturb you, indeed.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: 'Gad so, Sir, I beg your pardonâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No harm done in the least, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: You look like a civil Personâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O, a very civil Person.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: You may have an Interest in the Lady, to speak a good word for me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: VVhy, so I may; I may speak a good word for you indeed. But for your comfort, I can tell you, she has the Grace never to mind what I say to her.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Then do me the courtesie to leave us together, and I shall be able to speak for my self.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I never doubted it.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I suppose you may be her Grandfather; 'tis your business, you know, to provide for your Family.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And why her Grandfather, pray?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Because you look to be about those years of discretion.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come, you are an idle Companion, to talk at this rate to my VVife, and before my face too.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: How, Sir, your VVife! is she your VVife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I am her Husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I beg your pardon again, Sir; I was in hopesâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I know you were; you were in hopes to make me a Cuckold: But you are an impudent Fellow for your hopes; and so get you gone about your business. Ha! what's the matter with me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: VVhy, Husband, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I am so drowsie all on the suddenâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: The Glass stays for you, Fernando.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I'll Drink no more. VVife, let us go home.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: One Glass to the Bride, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O, are you there? You have a Daughter of mine in keeping, I take it; wish you Joy of her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your wishes will go a great way to't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No farther; [Yawns.] they will go no farther I tell you. VVife, VVife, let us be going VVife. Sure I am Enchantedâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Come, come, Fernando, you will take your Daughter into favour I know.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Pray give me leaveâ€”

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To depart in Peace.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: VVhat I ought to doâ€”

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: VVe shall know when he rises.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I leave you to consider itâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Upon his Pillow.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: VVife, VVife, come along with me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I'll take care of my Father; take no notice, but come as soon as you can to me.
sp.stage: [Fabian has Fernando carry'd off in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I may take care of you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: VVhat have we here?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Something is well meant:
Let us receive it so. Pray sit my Friends.

div.stage: An Entertainment of Dancing; after which a Song sent by an unknown hand, set by Mr. Henry Purcell, and Sung by Mrs. Ayliff.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I Sigh'd, and own'd my Love:
Nor did the Fair my Passion disapprove:
A soft engaging Air,
Not often apt to cause Despair,
Declar'd she gave attention to my Pray'r.
She seem'd to pity my Distress,
And I expected nothing less,
Than what her every look does now confess.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But, Oh, her change destroys
The Charming prospect of my promis'd Joys:
She's Rob'd of every Grace
That argu'd pity in her Face,
And cold, forbidding frowns, supply their place.
But while she strives to chill desire,
Her brighter Eyes such warmth inspire,
She checks the flame, but cannot quench the fire.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: You have not minded this poor Pageantry.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I minded what you said; you are to leave me:
I'm sorry for the cause.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O cou'd I think;
Cou'd I perswade my self, that your concern
For me, or for my absence, had employed youâ€”
But you are all possess'd another way.
I shall be Jealous of this Rival, Grief,
That you indulge; it sits so near your Heart,
There is not room enough for mighty Love.
We come. You, Carlos,
Will act a Brothers part, till my return;
And be the Guardian here. All, all I have,
That's dear to me, I give up to your care.
Our Dinner calls upon us: wou'd I had
An Entertainment that cou'd speak my Joy,
And thanks to this kind company. Lead on.
Long suff'ring Lovers wou'd consent to stay,
For the reward of such a Night and Day.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I. The Monastery Burying-place, Fernando's Tomb; Jaqueline, with others, Dress'd for Procession.
div.stage: Enter Fabian, with Carlos, Julia, Frederick, and Victoria.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: BE satisfied, and expect the consequence.
If I don't answer your expectations,
Never rely upon me for a Miracle again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O, but this is carrying the jest too far; he has beaten him like a Dog.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: VVhere have you buried him?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: This is his Tomb.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Then here lies an honest Fellow, who (if his VVife
VVould have heard reason) might have been
A Cuckold, and consequently gone to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But now he's buried, 'tis too late, you know,
To think of sending him that way.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: O Virtue! Virtue! what an Enemy art thou to a
Womans good Inclinations!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A troublesome Companion indeed, if one knew how to be honestly rid on't: Can you advise me?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay, take your own way; you are past advising, it seems; for a Woman to play the Hypocrite, and counterfeit Virtue, when she has it not, is a very common thingâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But to play the Hypocrite, the wrong way!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To pretend to be a Woman of pleasure, and not have the benefit of the Characterâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Is what, it seems, you are not acquainted with. But for the future, Sir, you may helieve there are Women, who won't be provoked to injure their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there's a Letter for you at home.
The Messenger will deliver it to no body, but your self.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How, I must look about me then, I'le go with you.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I think I hear him stir in the Tomb.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: We'll be within call, Jaquelin, begin as soon as you please.
sp.stage: [Fernando pushes off the Tomb Stone, and stares about.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Heigh ho! where am I now! who are you? what wou'd you have with me? ha!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Bless us! what do I see! appropinquote in nomineâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O good Sir! have a care of your hard words; you may raise the Devil before you'r aware of it; I have had too much of his company already.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Avaunt, speak I conjure thee; if thou art the Devilâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O, no, Sir, I am none of the Devil; though I have seen him very lately.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Truly that's a very hard question at present; when I was in the land of the living, my name was Fernando, an old Jealous, Covetous Fellow; but what I am in this Country, whether I am Fernando, or noâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Fernando! save thee Fernando! what coming out of thy grave!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: From whence I am coming, or whither I am going, I can't tell you; but I have been in very bad Company I remember; I have seen the Devil.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Our prayers are heard; we have been fasting, and praying thee out of Purgatory, ever since thou wert buried.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Buried! have I been buried too?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: And now coming by thy grave in procession, what a Miracle is wrought for thee, to bring thee to life again!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, if I am alive again, 'tis a Miracle, that's certain; but are you sure I am alive?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Why, don't you find you are alive?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, I have been so often mistaken of late, I don't know what to say to't; I thought I was alive in Purgatory; and stood in't a good while; but there's no contending with the Devil in his own Dominions you know; I was forc't to confess my self, at last, as dead as a Herring.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: O Fernando! be thankful for a good Wife and Son;
They have shewn themselves so, in their sorrow
For you, ever since you were buried.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ay, ay, I heard of 'em;
How have they done since I left 'em?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They have made a hard shift; their sorrow is pretty well
Over now; but 'twas a great while before they
Were to be comforted; a great while indeed
Before they could be persuaded to forget you;
But we must live by the living, you know.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: That's very true.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Your Son Fabian, upon your death, was releas'd
Out of the Monastery; It had been a pity, you know,
That a good Estate should have wanted an Heir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ay, so it had indeed.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yours was a very good one, I hear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So so, conpetent, and enough for me; as it is,
I shall be glad to enjoy it a little longer
I believe; I thank you, Sir, for bringing me to it again.
But my Wife, is my dear Wife well? You know her too?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: She has had a great many good offers, since your death:
And truly 'twas very much for a young Widow
To refuse 'em; but she resolves never to Marry again.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: A lack a day! I am beholden to herâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: They say you were jealous of herâ€”

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Indeed I am, very much beholden to her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That you were extreamly jealous.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Alas! alas! I do confess it; I was an old Fool;
And she was too good for me:
But if I ever see her againâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Here they come, your Virtuous Wife,
And Son; pray learn to value 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Fabian, Julia, Frederick, and Victoria.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I'st possible!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: VVhat! risen from the dead!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: May I believe my Eyes?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may believe your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The very Shrowd my Husband was buried in!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The very same, the very same; pray help me
Out on't, as soon as you can, for I look but odly, I believe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: VVell enough truly Sir, for a Man, that has been buried. You look well enough, but you smell a little of the place, you come from, that I must own to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay like enough, though I don't pereceive it my self.
But have I been buried long enough to stink then?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Fie, Sir, stink! You don't positively stink;
You have only an earthy savour, or so, with lying
In the Grave without eating; that's all, I believe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, when I was alive, my Breath was none
Of the best, especially from an empty Stomach.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A day or two more had made it intollerable.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ah, VVife! I have suffered a great deal upon your accountâ€”

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Alas! upon my account!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Upon the account of my Jealousie; but I deserv'd it:
Jealousie is a damnable Sin there,
I shall never be Jealous more.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis well it has wrought that cure upon you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, You shall henceforward, go when, and where
You please; come when, and how you please;
Say what, and to whom, you please; and in fine,
If you have a mind to be reveng'd of me,
You shall make me what you please:
And that, I'm sure, will please you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Leave that to me Husband.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: Fabian you look Melancholly; Don't be sorry that I am alive again: You have some Friends in the other World, that put me in mind of you: I'll settle half my Estate upon you in present; and when I dieâ€”Who's that Frederick? You Marry'd my Daughter I remember.â€”

sp.speaker: Vict
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I had more Grace, than to dispose of my self without your consent; and more respect for your Family, than to Marry any Man without a Portion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If you please to give a Blessing to our Endeavours,
We have agreed upon the point to make you a Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why that's well said: You have my consent; Marry her, and I'll give her a Portion; but be sure you are as good as your word.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.p: In making me a Grandfather: I am so over-joy'd that I am alive again, I care not how many Children I have to provide for.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: You see the fruits of Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll keep out of Purgatory I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O don't name it good Son-in-Law:
I shall never get it out of my mind; that's certain.

Come my dear Wife, and Children, I owe my deliverance to your Intercession, and Piety: since you have brought me to Life again: You shall have no cause, for the future, to wish me Dead: Some fifty Years hence, I may be contented to go to Heaven; without calling by the way.
In the mean time, Husbands who doubt my Story,
May find in Jealousie their Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: The longest Day will have an end:
We are got home at last.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: We have got our Legs at Liberty;
And Liberty is Home, where'er we go:
ThÃ´ mine lies most in England.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Pray let me call this yours:
For what I can command in Bruxelles, you
Shall find your own. I have a Father here,
Who, perhaps, after Seven Years absence,
And costing him nothing in my Travels,
may be glad to see me. You know my Storyâ€”
How does my Beard become me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Just as you would have it,
'Tis Natural, and not your own.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: To Morrow you shall be sure to find me here,
As Early, as you please. This is the House;
You have observ'd the Street.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I warrant you; I han't many Visits
To make, before I come to you.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: To Night I have some affairs,
That will oblige me to be private.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A good Bed is the privatest Affair,
That I desire to be engaged in, to Night:
Your directions will carry me to my Lodgings.
sp.stage: Biron knocks again. Sampson enters to him.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Who's there? What would you have?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Is your Lady at home, Friend?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Why, truly Friend, it is my employment to answer impertinent Questions. But for my Ladies being at home, or no, that's just as my Lady pleases.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: But how shall I know, whether it pleases her or no?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Why, if you'll take my word for it, you may carry your Errand back again: She never pleases to see any body, at this time of Night, that she does not know; and, by the length of your Beard, you may be grown out of her remembrance.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: But I have business; and you don't know how that may please her.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Nay, if you have business, she is the best Judge,
Whether your business will please her or no:
Therefore I will proceed in my Office,
And know of my Lady, whether or no
She is pleas'd to be at home, or noâ€”

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Who's that you are so busie withal? methinks
You might have found out an answer in fewer words:
But Sampson, you love to hear your self prate sometimes,
As well as your betters, that I must say for you.
Let me come to him; who wou'd you speak with?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: With you, Mistress, if you can help me to speak to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I can help you, in a civil way: But can no body do your business but my Lady?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Not so well: But if you'll carry her this Ring,
She'll know my business better.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: There's no Love-Letter in it, I hope:
You look like a civil Gentleman:
In an honest way I may bring you an answer.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: My old Nurse, only a little older!
They say the Tongue grows always: Mercy on me!
Then hers is seven years longer, since I left her.
Yet there's something in these Servants folly
Pleases me: The cautious conduct of the Family
Appears, and speaks in their impertinence.
Well, Mistressâ€”

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I have deliver'd your Ring, Sir, pray Heav'n
You bring no bad News along with you.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Quite contrary, I hope.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Nay, I hope so too; but my Lady was very much surpriz'd when I gave it her. Sir, I am but a Servant, as a body may say, but if you'll walk in, that I may shut the Doors, for we keep very orderly hours, I can show you into the Parlour, and help you to an answer, perhaps, as soon as those that are wiser.

div.head: SCENE III. A Bed-Chamber.
div.stage: A Woman Servant spreading a Table.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I've heard of Witches, Magick Spells, and Charms, that have made Nature start from her old course: The Sun has been Eclips'd, the Moon drawn down from her career, still paler, and subdu'd to the abuses of this under World: Now I believe all possible. This Ring, this little Ring, with Necromantick force, has rais'd the Ghost of Pleasure to my fears; Conjur'd the sense of Honour, and of Love, into such Shapes, they fright me from my self: I dare not think of themâ€”
I'll call you when I want you.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Madam, the Gentleman's below.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I had forgot, pray let me speak with him.

This Ring was the first Present of my Love, to Biron, my first Husband: I must blush to think I have a second: Biron Dy'd (still to my loss) at Candy; there's my hope. O! Do I live to hope that he Dy'd there! It must be so: He's Dead; and this Ring left by his last breath, to some known, faithful Friend, to bring me back again.
That's all I have to trust toâ€”
My fears were Womans: I have view'd him all: And let me, let me say it to my self, I live again, and rise but from his Tomb.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.p: Have you forgot me quite?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Forgot you!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Then farewel my Disguise, and my Misfortunes.
My Isabella!
sp.stage: [He goes to her, she shrieks, and falls into a swoon.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: O! come again: Thy Biron summons thee to Life and
Love; once I had Charms to wake thee.
Thy once lov'd, ever loving Husband calls:
Thy Biron speaks to thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My Husband! Biron!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Excess of Love, and Joy, for my return,
Has over-power'd herâ€”I was to blame
To take thy Sexes softness unprepar'd:
But sinking thus, thus Dying in my Arms,
This extasie has made my welcom more
Than words cou'd say: Words may be Counterfeit,
False Coyn'd, and Current only from the Tongue,
Without the Mind; but Passion's in the Soul,
And always speaks the Heart.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where have I been? Why do you keep him from me?
I know his Voice: My Life, upon the Wing,
Hears the soft lure that brings me back again.
'Tis he himself, my Biron, the dear Man!
My true lov'd Husband! Do I hold you fast,
Never to part again? Can I believe it?
Nothing, but you, could work so great a change.
There's more than Life it self in Dying here:
If I must fall, 'tis welcom in these Arms.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Live ever in these Arms.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: But pardon me,
Excuse the wild disorder of my Soul:
The strange, surprizing Joy of seeing you,
Of seeing you again; Distracted meâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Thou Everlasting Goodness!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Answer me:
What hand of Providence has brought you back
To your own Home again? O satisfie
Th' impatience of my Heart: I long to know
The Story of your Sufferings. You wou'd think
Your Pleasures sufferings, so long remov'd
From Isabella's Love: But tell me all,
For every thought confounds me.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: My best life! at leisure, all.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: We thought you Dead; kill'd at the Siege of Candy.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: There I fell, among the Dead:
But hopes of Life reviving from my Wounds,
I was preserv'd, but to be made a Slave
I often writ to my hard Father, but never had
An Answer. I writ to thee tooâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What a world of Woe
Had been prevented, but in hearing from you!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Alas! thou could'st not help me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You do not know how much I cou'd ha' done;
At least, I'm sure I cou'd have suffer'd all:
I wou'd have sold my self to Slavery,
Without Redemption; giv'n up my Child,
The dearest part of me, to basest wantsâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: My little Boy!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My Life, but to have heard
You were aliveâ€”which now too late I find.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: No more, my Love! complaining of the past,
We lose the present Joy: 'Tis over Price,
Of all my pains, that thus we meet again.
I have a thousand things to say to theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Wou'd I were past the Hearing.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: How does my Child, my Boy? My Father too,
I hear, is living still.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Well, both, both well:
And may he prove a Father to your hopes;
Tho' we have found him none.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Come, no more Tears.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Seven long years of sorrow for your loss,
Have mourn'd with meâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: And all my days behind
Shall be employed in a kind recompense
For thy afflictionsâ€”Can't I see my Boy?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: He's gone to Bed: I'le have him brought to you.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: To morrow I shall see him; I want rest
My self, after my weary Pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Alas! What shall I get for you?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Nothing but rest, my Love! to night I would not
Be known, if possible, to your Family;
I see my Nurse is with you; her welcome
Would be tedious at this time;
To morrow will do better

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I' â€¢ e dispose of her, and order every thing
As you would have it.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Grant me but Life, good Heav'n, and give the means
To make this wondrous Goodness some amends;
And let me then forget her, if I can!
O! she deserves of me much more, than I
Can lose for her, though I again cou'd venture
A Father, and his Fortune, for her Love.
You wretched Fathers! blind as fortune all!
Not to perceive that such a Womans worth
Weighs down the Portions, you provide your Sons.
What has she, in my absence, undergone?
I must not think of that; it drives me back
Upon my self, the fated cause of all.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have obeyed your pleasure;
Every thing is ready for you.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I can want nothing here; possessing thee,
All my desires have carry'd to their aim
Of happiness; there's no room for a wish,
But to continue still this blessing to me.
I know the way, my Love; I shall sleep sound.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Shall I help to undress you?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: By no means;
I've been so long a slave to others pride,
To learn, at least, to wait upon my self;
You'l make haste afterâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I'le but say my Prayers, and follow youâ€”
My Prayers! no, I must never Pray again.
Prayers have their Blessings to reward our Hopes;
But I have nothing left to hope for more.
What Heaven cou'd give, I have enjoy'd; but now
The baseful Planet rises on my fate,
And what's to come, is a long line of woe;
Yet I may shorten itâ€”
I promis'd him to followâ€”him!
Is he without a name? Biron, my Husband:
To follow him to Bedâ€”my Husband! ha!
What then is Villeroy? but yesterday
That very Bed receiv'd him for its Lord;
Yet a warm witness of my broken vows,
To send another to usurp his room.
O Biron! had'st thou come but one day sooner,
I wou'd have follow'd thee through beggary;
Through all the chances of this very Life,
Wandred the many ways of wretchedness
With thee, to find a hospitable grave.
For that's the only bed, that's left me now.
â€”What's to be doneâ€”for something must be done.
Two Husbands! yet not one! by both enjoy'd,
And yet a Wife to neither! hold my Brainâ€”
This is to live in common; very Beasts,
That welcome all they meet, make just such Wives.
My reputation! O, 'twas all was left me;
The vertuous pride of an uncensur'd life;
Which, the dividing Tongues of Biron's wrongs,
And Villeroy's resentments tear asunder,
To gorge the Throats of the Blaspheming Rabble.
This is the best of what can come to morrow.
Besides old Baldwin's triumph in my ruine.
I cannot bear itâ€”
Therefore no morrow. Ha! a lucky thought
Works the right way to rid me of 'em all,
All the reproaches, infamies, and scorns,
That every Tongue, and Finger will find for me.
Let the just horror of my apprehensions
But keep me warmâ€”no matter what can come.
'Tis but a blowâ€”if it should miss my Heart
â€”But every part is mortal to such wounds.
Yet I will see him firstâ€”
Have a last look to heighten my despair,
And then to rest for everâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Despair! and rest for ever! Isabella!
These words are far from thy condition;
And be they ever so. I heard thy voice;
And cou'd not bear thy absence; come, my Love!
You have stay'd long; there's nothing, nothing sure
Now to despair of in succeeding fate.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am contented to be miserable,
But not this way; I've been too long abus'd,
And can believe no more;
Let me sleep on, to be deceiv'd no more.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Look up, my Love, I never did deceive thee,
Nor ever can; believe thy self, thy Eyes,
That first enflam'd, and lit me to thy Love,
Those Stars, that still must guide me to my Joys.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And me to my undoing I look round,
And find no path, but leading to the Grave.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I cannot understand thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My good Friends above,
I thank 'em, have at last found out a way,
To make my fortune perfect; having you,
I need no more; my Fate is finished here.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Both our ill Fates I hope.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hope is a lying, fawning Flatterer,
That shews the fair side only of our fortunes,
To cheat us easier into our fall;
A trusted Friend, who only can betray you;
Never believe him more. If Marriages
Are made in Heaven, they should be happier.
Why was I made this Wretch?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: His Marriage made thee wretched?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Miserable beyond the reach of comfort.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Do I live to hear thee say so?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why! What did I say?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: That I have made thee miserable.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No: You are my only Earthly Happiness.
And my false Tongue bely'd my honest Heart,
If it said otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: And yet you said,
Your Marriage made you Miserable.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I know not what I said:
I've said too much, unless I could speak all.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Thy words are wild; my Eyes, my Ears, my Heart
Were all so full of thee, so much employ'd
In wonder of thy Charms, I could not find it:
Now I perceive it plain.â€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You'l tell no bodyâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Thou art not well.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Indeed I am not: I knew that before,
But where's the remedy?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Rest will relieve thy Cares: Come, come, no more;
I'll Banish sorrow from thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Banish first the cause.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Heav'n knows how willingly.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You are the only cause.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Am I the cause? The cause of thy Misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: The Fatal Innocent cause of all my Woes.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Is this my welcome Home? This the reward
Of all my Miseries, long Labours, Pains,
And pining wants of Wretched Slavery,
Which I have out-liv'd, only in hopes of thee?
Am I thus paid at last for Deathless Love?
And call'd the Cause of thy Misfortunes now?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Enquire no more; 'twill be explain'd too soon.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: What! Can'st thou leave me too?
sp.stage: She is going. He stays her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Pray let me go:
For both our sakes permit me.â€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Rack me not with Imaginations
Of things impossible:â€”Thou can'st not mean
What thou hast saidâ€”Yet something she must mean,
â€”'Twas Madness allâ€”Compose thy self, my Love!
The fit is past; all may be well again.
Let us to Bed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To Bed! You've rais'd the storm
Will sever us for ever. O my Biron!
While I have life, still I must call you mine:
I know I am, and always was unworthy
To be the happy partner of your love:
And now must never, never share it more.
But, oh! if ever I was dear to you,
As sometimes you have thought me; on my Knees,
(The last time I shall care to be believ'd)
I beg you, beg to think me innocent,
Clear of all Crimes, that thus can banish me
From this Worlds comforts, in my losing you.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Where will this end?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: The rugged hand of Fate has got between
Our meeting Hearts, and thrusts 'em from their Joys.
Since we must partâ€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Nothing shall ever part us.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Partings the least that is set down for me:
Heaven has decreed, and we must suffer all.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I know thee Innocent; I know my self so.
Indeed we both have been Unfortunate:
But sure Misfortunes ne'er were faults in Love.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh! There's a Fatal Story to be told;
Be deaf to that, as Heaven has been to me!
And rot the Tongue that shall reveal my Shame
When thou shalt hear how much thou hast been wrong'd,
How wilt thou Curse thy fond believing Heart,
Tear me from the warm bosom of thy Love,
And throw me like a pois'nous Weed away.
Can I bear that? Bear to be curst and torn,
And thrown out from thy Family and Name,
Like a Disease? Can I bear this from thee?
I never can; No, all things have their end.
When I am dead, forgive, and pity me.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Yet stay, if the sad News at last must come,
Thou art my Fate, and best may speak my Doom.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I Know enough; th'important question
Of Life or Death, fearful to be resolv'd,
Is clear'd to me: I see where it must end;
And need enquire no moreâ€”Pray let me have
Pen, Ink, and Paper, I must write a while,
And then I'll try to restâ€”to rest! for ever.
Poor Isabella! Now I know the cause,
The cause of thy distress, and cannot wonder
That it has turn'd thy Brain. If I look back
Upon thy loss, it will distract me too.
O, any Curse but this might be remov'd!
But 'twas the rancorous Malignity
Of all ill Stars combin'd, of Heaven, and Fate,
To put it quite out of their Mercies reach,
To speak Peace to us; if they cou'd repent,
They cannot help us now. Alas! I rave:
Why do I tax the Stars, or Heaven, or Fate?
They are all innocent of driving us
Into Despair; they have not urg'd my Doom.
My Father, and my Brother are my Fates,
That drive me to my ruine They knew well
I was alive: Too well they knew how dear
My Isabellaâ€”O my Wife no more!
How dear her love was to meâ€”Yet they stood,
With a malicious silent joy, stood by,
And saw her give up all my happiness,
The treasure of her Beauty to another:
Stood by, and saw her Married to another.
O Cruel Father! and Unnatural Brother?
Shall I not tell you that you have undone me?
I have but to accuse you of my wrongs,
And then to fall forgotten.â€”Sleep, or Death,
Sits heavy on me, and benums my pains:
Either is welcome; but the hand of Death
Works always sure, and best can close my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Here's strange things towards, Sampson:
What will be the end of 'em, do you think?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Nay, marry Nurse, I can't see so far; but the Law
I believe, is on Biron, the first Husband's side.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Yes; No Question, he has the Law on his side.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: For I have heard, the Law says, a Woman must be a Widow, all out Seven Years, before she can Marry again, according to Law.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Ay, so it does; and our Lady has not been a Widow altogether Seven Years.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Why then, Nurse, mark my words, and say I told you so: The Man must have his Mare again, and all will do well.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: But if our new Master Villeroy comes back again.â€”

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Why, if he does, he is not the first Man, that has had his Wife taken from him.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: For fear of the worst, will you go to the old Count, desire him to come as soon as he can, there may be mischief, and he is able to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Now you say something, now I take you, Nurse, that will do well indeed: Mischief should be prevented; a little thing will make a quarrel, when there's a Woman in the way. I'll about it instantly.â€”
sp.stage: Scene drawn, shews Biron asleep on a Couch. Isabella comes in to him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Asleep so soon! O happy! happy thou!
Who thus can'st sleep: I never shall sleep more.
If then to sleep be to be happy, he
Who sleeps the longest, is the happiest;
Death is the longest sleep. O! have a care,
Mischief will thrive apace. Never wake more;
If thou didst ever love thy Isabella,
To Morrow must be Doomsday to thy peace.
â€”The sight of him disarms ev'n Death it self.
â€”The starting transport of new quick'ning Life,
Gives just such hopes; and Pleasure grows again
With looking on himâ€”Let me look my lastâ€”
But is a look enough for parting Love!
Sure I may take a Kissâ€”where am I going!
Help, help me, Villeroy!â€”Mountains, and Seas
Divide your loves, never to meet my Shame.
sp.stage: [Throws her self on the Floor; after a short pause. she raises her self upon her Elbow.
sp.l: What will this Battle of the Brain do with me!
This little Ball, this ravag'd Province, long
Cannot maintainâ€”The Globe of Earth wants room,
And food for such a Warâ€”I find I'm goingâ€”
Famine, Plagues, and Flames,
Wide waste and desolation, do your work
Upon the World, and then devour your selves.
â€”The Scene shifts fastâ€” [She rises] and now 'tis better with me.
Conslicting Passions have at last unhing'd
The great Machine; the Soul it self seems chang'd:
O, 'tis a happy revolution here!
The reas'ning faculties are all depos'd,
Judgment, and Understanding, Common sense,
Driv'n out; as Traytors to the publick Peace.
Now I'm reveng'd upon my memory,
Her seat dug up, where all the Images
Of a long mispent Life, were rising still,
To glare a sad reflexion of my crimes,
And stab a Conscience through 'em. You are safe
You Monitors of Mischief! What a change!
Better and better still! This is the infant state
Of Innocence, before the birth of care.
My thoughts are smooth as the Elysian Plains
Without a rub: The drowzy falling streams
Invite me to their Slumbers.
Would I were landed thereâ€”
What Noise was that! A knocking at the Gate!
It may be Villeroy!â€”No matter who.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Come, Isabella, comeâ€”

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hark, I am call'd.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: You stay too long from me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: A Mans Voice! in my Bed! how came he there?
Nothing but villany in this bad World;
Coveting Neighbours Goods, or Neighbours Wives;
Cuckolds, or Cuckold-makers every where;
Here's Physick for your Fever;
sp.stage: [Draws a Dagger and goes backward to the Coach.
sp.l: Breathing a Vein is the old remedy.
Why, at this rate, 'tis impossible for an
Honest Man to keep his Wife to himself;
The trade must thrive they say.
If Husbands go to Heaven,
Where do they go, that send 'em?â€”This to try.
sp.stage: [Just going to stab him, he rises, she knows him.
sp.l: What do I see!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: My Isabella! arm'd!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Against my Husbands life!
Who, but the Wretch, most reprobate to grace,
Despair e're hardned for damnation,
Cou'd think of such a deed! Murder my Husband!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Thou didst not think it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Madness has brought me to the Gates of Hell,
And here has left me. O the frightful change
Of my distractions! or is this interval
Of reason, but to aggravate my woes;
To drive the horror back with greater force,
Upon my Soul, and fix me mad for ever?

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Why dost thou fly me so?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I cannot bear his sight; distraction, come,
Possess me all, and take me to thy self;
Shake off thy chains, and hasten to my aid;
Thou art my only cureâ€”like other Friends,
He wonnot come to my necessities;
Then I must go to find the Tyrant out;
Which is the nearest way?â€”

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Poor Isabella, she's not in a condition,
To give me any comfort, if she cou'd;
Lost to her self; as quickly I shall be
To all the World. Death had been most welcome,
From any hand but hers; she never cou'd
Deserve to be the Executioner,
To take my Life; nor I to fall by her.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Sir, there's some body at the Door, must needs
Speak with you; he won't tell his Name.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I come to himâ€”
'Tis Bellford I suppose; he little knows
Of what has hapned here; I wanted him,
And must employ his friendshipâ€”

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A younger Brother! I was one too long.
Not to prevent my being so againâ€”
We must be suddainâ€”Younger Brothers are
But lawful Bastards of another Name,
Thrust out of their Nobility of Birth,
And Family, and tainted into Trades.
Shall I be one of 'em? bow, and retire,
To make more room, for the unwieldly Heir
To play the fool in? No.
But how shall I prevent it! Biron comes,
To take possession of my Fathers love;
Wou'd that were all; there is a birth-right too
That he will seizeâ€”besides, if Biron lives
He will unfold some practices, which I
Cannot well answerâ€”therefore he shall dye;
This night must be disposed of: I have means
That will not fail my purposeâ€”Here he comes;
Be sure you murder him.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: Ha! Am I beset? I live but to revenge me.
sp.stage: [They surround him fighting, Villeroy enters with two Servants, they rescue him, Carlos and his Party run, Biron very much wounded, one of Villeroy's Servants strugling on the ground with one of the Ruffians.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: How are you, Sir? mortally hurt I fear;
Take care, and lead him in.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here's one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O 'Tis very well; I'le make you an example.
sp.stage: Scene changes to the inside of the House.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Murder my Husband! O! I must not dare
To think of living on; my desperate hand
In a mad rage, may offer it again;
Stab any where, but there. Here's room enough
In my own Breast, to act the fury in,
The proper Scene of mischief. Villeroy comes;
Villeroy, and Biron come: O! hide me from 'emâ€”
They rack, they tear; let 'em carve out my limbs,
Divide my body to their equal claims:
My Soul is only Biron's; that is free,
And thus I strike for him, and liberty.
sp.stage: [Going to stab her self, Villeroy runs in, and prevents her, by taking the Dagger from her.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Angels defend, and save thee!
Attempt thy pretious Life! the treasury
Of Natures sweets! life of my little World!
Lay violent hands upon thy innocent self!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Swear I am innocent, and I'le believe you.
What wou'd you have with me? pray let me go.
â€”Are you there, Sir? You are the very Man,
Have done all thisâ€”You wou'd have made
Me believe, you married me; but the Fool
Was wiser I thank you; 'tis not all Gospel
You Men preach upon that subject.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Dost thou not know me?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O, yes, very well.
You are the Widows Comforter, that Marries
Any Woman, when her Husband's out of the way.
But I'le never, never take your word again.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I am thy loving Husband.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have none; no Husbandâ€”
Never had but one, and he Dy'd at Candy:
Did he not? I'm sure you told me so; you,
Or some body, with just, just such a lying look,
As you have now: Speak, did he not Dye there?

sp.speaker: Vil
sp.l: He did my Life!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: But swear it, quickly-swear,
sp.stage: [Biron enters bloody, and leaning upon his Sword.
sp.l: Before that screaming Evidence appears,
In bloody proof against meâ€”
sp.stage: [She seeing Biron swoons into a Chair, Vil. helps her.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Help there, Nurse, where are you?
Ha! I am distracted too!
sp.stage: [Going to call for help sees Biron.
sp.l: Biron alive!

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: The only wretch on Earth, that must not live.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Biron, or Villeroy must not, that's Decreed.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: You've sav'd me from the hands of Murderers:
Wou'd you had not, for Life's my greatest plague:
And then of all the World, you are the Man
I wou'd not be oblig'd toâ€”Isabella!
I came to fall before thee: I had dy'd
Happy, not to have found your Villeroy here.
A long farewel, and a last parting Kiss.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A Kiss! Confusion! It must be your last.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: I know it mustâ€”here I give up that Death
You but delay'd. Since what is past has been
The work of Fate, thus we must finish it.
Thrust home be sureâ€”.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Alas! he faints! Some help there.

sp.speaker: Bir.
sp.l: This Letter is my last, last Dying care;
Give it my Fatherâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: He's gone: Let what will be the consequence,
I'll give it him. I have involv'd my self,
And wou'd be clear'd; that must be thought on now.
My care of her is lost in wild amaze.
Are you all Dead within there? Where, where are you?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where have I been! methinks I stand upon
The brink of Life, ready to shoot the Gulph,
That lies between me, and the Realms of Rest;
But still detain'd, I cannot pass the Streight:
Deny'd to live, and yet I must not Dye.
Doom'd to come back, like a complaining Ghost,
To my Unburied Bodyâ€”Here it lies,
My Body, Soul, and Life. A little Dust
To cover our cold Limbs in the dark Grave,
Then, then we shall sleep safe and sound together.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Poor wretch! Upon the Ground! She's not her self,
Remove her from the Body.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Never, never:
You have Divorc'd us once, but shall no more.
Help, help me Biron; Ha! Bloody and Dead!
O Murder, Murder! You have done this Deed!
Vengeance! and Murder! Bury us together;
Do any thing but part us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Gently, gently raise herâ€”
She must be forc'd away.
sp.stage: [She drags the Body after her, they get her into their Arms, and carry her off.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O, they tear me! Cut off my Hands,
Let me leave something with him,
They'll clasp him fastâ€”
O cruel, cruel Men!
This you must answer one Day.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Good Nurse, take care of her:
Send for all helps: All, all that I am worth,
Shall cheaply buy her Peace of Mind again.
Besure you do
Just as I order'd you. The Storm grows loud,
I am prepar'd for it; now let them in.
sp.stage: Enter Count Baldwin, Carlos, Bellford, Frederick, with Servants.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: O do I live to this Unhappy day!
Where is my wretched Son?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is my Brother?
sp.stage: [They see, and gather about the Body.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I hope in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Can'st thou pity him,
Wish him in Heaven? When thou hast done a Deed,
That must for ever cut thee from the hopes
Of ever coming there.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I do not blame you.
You have a Brothers Right to be concern'd
For his untimely Deathâ€”

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Untimely Death indeed!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But yet you must not say, I was the cause.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not you the cause! why, who shou'd Murder him?
We do not ask you to accuse your self:
But I must say that you have Murder'd him:
And will say nothing else, till Justice draws
Upon our side, at the loud call of Blood,
To execute so foul a Murderer.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor Biron! Is this thy welcom home?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Rise, Sir, there is a comfort in Revenge,
Which yet is left you

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Take the Body hence.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: What cou'd provoke you?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Nothing could provoke me
To a base Murder; which, I find, you think
Me guilty of: I know my Innocence:
My Servants too can Witness, that I d â€¢ ew
My Sword in his Defence, to Rescue him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let the Servants be call'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let's hear what they can say.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What they can say! Why, what shou'd Servants say!
They're his Accomplices, his Instruments,
And won not charge themselves. If they cou'd do
A Murder for his Service; they can lye,
Lye nimbly; and swear hard to bring him off.
You say, you drew your Sword in his Defence:
Who were his Enemies? Did he need Defence?
Had he wrong'd any one? Cou'd he have a cause
To apprehend a danger but from you?
And yet you Rescu'd him! No, no, he came
Unseasonably, (that was all his Crime)
Unluckily to interrupt your sport:
You were new Marry'd, Marry'd to his Wife;
And therefore you, and she, and all of you,
(For all of you I must believe concern'd)
Combin'd to Murder him out of the way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If it be so.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It can be only so.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Indeed it has a Face.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As black as Hell.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: The Law will do me Justice: Send for the Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll go my self for himâ€”

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: These strong Presumptions, I must own indeed,
Are violent against me; but I have
A Witness, and on this side Heav'n too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What cries are those?
sp.stage: [The Scene opens, shows Pedro on a Rack.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Open that Door:
Here's one can tell you all.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: All, all: Take me but from the Rack I'll confess all.
I can hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You, and your Accomplices design'd
To Murder Biron? Speak.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We did.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Did you engage upon your private wrongs,
Or were employ'd?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He never did us wrong.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You were set on then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O! we were set on.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What do you know of me?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing:
You sav'd his Life; and have discovered me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Take him down.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: He has acquitted me.
If you wou'd be resolv'd of any thing,
He stands upon his answer.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Who set you on to act this horrid Deed?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Kill me outright; let all the guilt be mine.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: I'll know the Villain; give me quick his Name,
Or I will tear it from thy bleeding Heart.
Pull hard, Rack, Torture himâ€”

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O! I confess.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Do then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It was my Master, Carlos, your own Son.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: O Monstrous! Monstrous! most Unnatural!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Did he employ you to Murder his own Brother?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He did, and he was with us when 'twas done.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: If this be true, which is impossible,
It is but Just upon me: Birons wrongs
Must be reveng'd; and I the cause of all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: VVhat will you do with him?

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Now take him down:
I know too much.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I had forgot: Your wretched, dying Son,
Gave me this Letter for you.
I dare deliver it: If it speaks of me,
I pray to have it read.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: You know the hand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I know 'tis Biron's hand.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.p: Pray Read it.

SIR, I find I am come home only to lay my Death at your Door: I am now going out of the World, but cannot forgive you, nor my Brother Carlos, for not hindring my poor Wife Isabella, from Marrying with Villeroy, when you both knew, from so many Letters, that I was alive.â€”
BIRON.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: How! Did you know it then?

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.p: Amazement! all.
O, Carlos! are you come? Your Brother here, here in a wretched Letter, lays his Death on you, and me: Have you done any thing to hasten his sad end?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Bless me, Sir, I do any thing? who, I!

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: He talks of Letters that were sent to us:
I never heard of any: Did you know he was alive?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alive! Heav'n knows, not I.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Had you no News of him, from a Report,
Or Letter never?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Never, never, I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That's strange indeed: I know he often writ
To lay before you the condition
Of his hard Slavery: And more I know,
That he had several Answers of his Letters:
He said they came from you; you are his Brother.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Never from me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That will appear.
The Letters I believe are still about him;
For some of 'em I saw but yesterday.

sp.speaker: C Bald.
sp.l: What did those answers say?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I cannot speak to the particulars;
But I remember well, the Sum of 'em
Was much the same, and all agreed,
That there was nothing to be hop'd from you;
That 'twas your barbarous resolution,
To let him perish there.

sp.speaker: C Bald.
sp.l: O Carlos! Carlos! hadst thou been a Brother.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This is a plot upon me; I never knew
He was in slavery, or was alive,
Or heard of him, before this fatal hour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: There, Sir, I must confront you.
He sent you a Letter, to my knowledge, last night;
And you sent him word you wou'd come to him:
I fear you came too soon.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: 'Tis all too plain.
Bring out that Wretch before him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha! Pedro there! then I am caught indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You start at sight of him,
He has confest the bloody deed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well then, he has confest,
And I must answer it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Is there no more?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why, what you have more? I know the worst,
And I expect it.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Why hast thou done all this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why that, that which damns most Men, has ruin'd me,
The making of my fortune. Biron stood
Between me, and your favour; while he liv'd,
I had not that; hardly was thought a Son;
And not at all a-kin to your Estate.
I could not bear a younger Brothers lot,
To live depending, upon curtesie.
Had you provided for me like a Father,
I had been still a Brother.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: 'Tis too true,
I never lov'd thee, as I shou'd have done;
It was my Sin, and I am punish'd for't.
O! never may distinction rise again
In Families: let Parents be the same
To all their Children; common in their Care,
And in their Love of 'em: I am unhappy
For loving one too well.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You knew your Brother liv'd; why did you take
Such pains to Marry me to Isabella?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I had my Reasons for'tâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: More than I thought you had.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But one was this;
I knew my Brother lov'd his Wife so well,
That if he ever shou'd come home again,
He cou'd not long out-live the loss of her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you rely'd on that, why did you kill him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To make all sure. Now you are answer'd all.
Where must I go? I'm tir'd of your Questions.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: I leave the Judge to tell thee what thou art;
A Father cannot find a Name for thee.
But Parricide is highest treason sure.
To sacred Natures laws; and must be so,
So sentenc'd in thy Crimes. Take him awayâ€”
The violent remedy is found at last,
That drives thee out, thou poyson of my Blood,
Infected long, and only foul in thee.
Grant me, sweet Heaven, thy patience, to go through
The torment of my cureâ€”Here, here begins
The Operationâ€”alas! she's mad.
sp.stage: [Isabella enters distracted, held by her Women, her Hair disheavel'd, her little Son running in before, being afraid of her.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: My Isabella! poor unhappy Wretch!
What can I say to her?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing, 'tis a babling VVorld,
I'le hear no more on't. VVhen does the Court sit?
I'll not be bought, what! To sell innocent Blood!
You look like one of the pale Judges here,
Minos, or Radamanth, or AEacus,
I have heard of you.
I have a Cause to try, an honest one;
Will you not hear it? Then I must appeal
To the bright Throne, call down the Heavenly powers,
To Witness how you use me.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Help, help, we cannot hold her.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You but enrage her more.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Pray give her way, she'l hurt no body.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What have you done with him? He was here but now;
I saw him here. Oh Biron, Biron! where,
Where have they hid thee from me? He is goneâ€”
But here's a little flaming Cherubinâ€”

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: O save me, save me!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: The Mercury of Heaven, with Silver VVings,
Impt for the flight, to overtake his Ghost,
And bring him back again.

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: I fear she'l kill me.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: She wonnot hurt thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: VVill nothing do! I did not hope to find
Justice on Earth; 'tis not in Heaven neither.
Biron has watch'd his opportunity.
Softly; He steals it from the sleeping Gods,
And sends it thus,
Now, now I laugh at you, defie you all,
You Tyrants, Murderers.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Call. call for help: O Heaven! This was too much.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: O! Thou most injur'd Innocence! Yet live,
Live but to VVitness for me to the VVorld,
How much I do repent me of the wrongs,
Th'unnatural wrongs, which I have heap'd on thee,
And have pull'd down this Judgment on us all.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O speak, speak but a word of comfort to me.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: If the most tender Fathers care, and love
Of thee, and thy poor Child can make amends;
O yet look up, and Live.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: VVhere is that little wretch?
I dye in Peace to leave him to your care.
I have a wretched Mothers Legacy,
A dying Kiss, pray let me give it him,
My blessing; that, that's all I have to leave thee.
O may thy Fathers Virtues live in thee:
And all his wrongs be buried in my Grave.
The VVaves and VVinds will dash, and Tempests roar;
But Wrecks are toss'd at last upon the Shore.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: She's gone, and all my Joys of Life with her.
Where are your Officers of Justice now?
Seize, bind me, drag me to the Bloody Bar,
Accuse, condemn me; Let the Sentence reach
My hated Life, no matter how it comes,
I'll think it just, and thank you as it falls.
Self Murder is deny'd me: Else how soon
Could I be past the pain of my remembrance!
But I must live, grow Gray with lingring Grief,
To dye at last in telling this sad Tale.

sp.speaker: C. Bald.
sp.l: Poor Wretched Orphan of most wretched Parents.
Scaping the Storm, thou'rt thrown upon a Rock,
To perish there; the very Rocks would melt;
Soften their Nature sure to foster thee:
I find it by my self. My Flinty Heart,
That Barren Rock, on which thy Father starv'd,
Opens its springs of Nourishment to thee:
There's not a Vein but shall run Milk for thee.
O had I pardon'd my poor Birons fault!
His first, his only fault, this had not been.
To erring Youth there's some compassion due;
But while with rigour you their crimes pursue,
What's their misfortune, is a crime in you.
Hence learn offending Children to forgive:
Leave punishment to Heav'n, 'tis Heav'ns Prerogative.

div.head: EPILOGUE, TO THE Fatal Marriage: Or, The Innocent Adultery.
Spoken by Mrs. Verbruggen.
div.l: NOw tell me, when you saw the Lady dye,
Were you not puzled for a Reason why?
A Buxom Dam'zel, and of Play-house race,
Not to out-live th'injoyment of a Brace!
Were that the only Marriage-curse in Store,
How many would compound to suffer more,
And yet live on, with comfort to threescore?
But on our Exits there is no relying:
We Women are so Whimsical in Dying.
Some pine away for loss of ogling Fellows:
Nay some have dy'd for Love, as Stories tell us.
Some, say our Histories, though long ago,
For having undergone a Rape, or so,
Plung'd the fell Dagger, without more ado.
But time has laugh'd these follies out of fashion:
And sure they'l never gain the approbation
Of Ladies, who consult their Reputation.
For if a Rape must be esteem'd a Curse,
Grim Death, and Publication make it worse.
Should the opinion of the World be try'd,
They'l scarce give Judgment on the Plaintiff's side.
For all must own, 'tis most egregious Nonsense,
To dye for being pleas'd, with a safe Conscience.
Nay, look not on your Fans, nor turn away,
For tell me, Ladies, why do you Marry, pray?
But to enjoy your Wishes, as you may.
